entry.title: How to Use SAP Extensibility Wizard in SAP S/4HANA Clean Core
entry.content:
A Comprehensive Guide to Extending SAP S/4HANA with the SAP Extensibility Wizard â€” Without Compromising Your Clean Core

Introduction

Extensibility is a critical aspect of SAP S/4HANA, enabling organizations to tailor the system to their unique business needs while maintaining stability and upgrade readiness. In this guide, we will explore the SAP Extensibility Wizard, a powerful tool designed to help developers extend SAP S/4HANA in a clean and controlled way.

What Is the SAP Extensibility Wizard?

The SAP Extensibility Wizard is a guided tool provided by SAP that simplifies the process of creating extensions. It ensures that developers can add custom functionality without modifying the core system, thereby preserving the clean core principle. This approach guarantees that upgrades remain smooth and that the system stays resilient over time.

Availability: Public Cloud vs. Private Cloud

A common question arises: Is the SAP Extensibility Wizard available only in the Public Cloud, or also in the Private Cloud?

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud â€“ Public Edition):
    The wizard is primarily available here. It supports clean-core extensibility and helps organizations build safe, upgradeâ€‘friendly extensions.
  • Private Cloud / Onâ€‘Premise:
    Extensibility is possible through other approaches such as inâ€‘app extensibility, ABAP Cloud, and sideâ€‘byâ€‘side extensions on SAP BTP. However, the wizard itself is not provided in the same way as in the Public Cloud.

In summary:

  • Public Cloud â†’ Wizard available.
  • Private Cloud / Onâ€‘Premise â†’ Extensibility options exist, but without the wizard.

Focus of This Blog

This blog will focus on the SAP Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud â€“ Public Edition.

How to Use the Extensibility Wizard

With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition extensibility wizard, developers can:

  • Create onâ€‘stack extensions such as custom fields and custom logic.
  • Build sideâ€‘byâ€‘side extensions like custom processes using SAP Build Process Automation.

This guided approach ensures that extensions are implemented efficiently, securely, and in alignment with SAPâ€™s cleanâ€‘core strategy.

Conclusion

The SAP Extensibility Wizard is a key enabler for organizations running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. By leveraging this tool, businesses can extend their systems with confidence, ensuring that customizations remain upgradeâ€‘safe and futureâ€‘proof.

 

Detailed Steps:

Use Case : We will create a sales order approval process .

1. Navigate to SAP S4/HANA Fiori Launchpad.

1.1 Select Business Application Manage Sales Orders. 

1.2  Navigate to Create Extension

 

1.3 In this case , we will select custom process.

The process can start based on various triggers 

1.4 Select Business Event from SAP S4/HANA, that Triggers the process

1.5 Select Event Object

1.6 Select the SalesOrder create event.

1.7 Click Preview to see all the options you selected on previous screens, and make any necessary corrections.

1.8 Click Create , to create the process in SAP Build.

1.9 The extension is now available and can also be opened in SAP Build.

1.10 When you select Open Extension, the system launches another tab that opens the process.

1.11 The Process Automation project overview page is now displayed. Select SalesOrder Approval.

1.12 Extension is now openEd in SAP Build , Start design of the process.

The Business context is carried over from SAP S4/HANA to SAP Build .

1.13 You can add an action, form , or approval . To get further details on the sales order, you need to call an action .

1.14 In this use case , we will call sales order read API , to fetch the sales order details.

1.15 Browse the library to search for  the relevant APIs .

1.16 Select read sales order API to get details of the sales order, The business context and system ID were automatically pulled in from SAP S4/HANA .

1.17 The action to read the sales order has now been added . Now users can design the process according to their needs. The user now wants to initiate a workflow that sends an email to the approver for sales order approval .

1.18 The email will include the sales order details , allowing approver to review and approve it . we're utilizing AI to generate the process , Enter the prompt to add an approval step and send the sales order details to the approver via email.

1.19 AI has now added the process step to read the sales order and email, The sales order details to the approver .

 

Conclusion

The SAP Extensibility Wizard empowers organizations running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to extend their systems safely and efficiently, without compromising the clean core. By leveraging guided tools for custom fields, logic, and sideâ€‘byâ€‘side processes, businesses can innovate while staying upgradeâ€‘ready.

Extensibility in SAP is not just about adding featuresâ€”itâ€™s about doing so in a way that keeps your system futureâ€‘proof. With the wizard, you can confidently build the extensions your business needs today, while ensuring smooth upgrades tomorrow.

entry.title: How to Create a ServiceNow Incident via REST API Using ABAP (OAuth 2.0)
entry.content:
Prerequisites

  • ServiceNow instance access with API credentials (Client ID, Client Secret)
  • SAP NetWeaver with HTTP Client (CL_HTTP_CLIENT) and JSON support (/UI2/CL_JSON)

Step 1: Obtain OAuth2 Token from ServiceNow

First, you need to POST your client credentials to ServiceNowâ€™s /oauth_token endpoint to get a bearer token. This token authorizes subsequent API calls.

ABAP Code:

FORM get_servicenow_token USING iv_token_url TYPE string
                              iv_client_id TYPE string
                              iv_client_secret TYPE string
                         CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
                                  cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, the access_token can now be used as a Bearer token.

Step 2: Build the JSON Payload

Create a JSON structure that describes the incident.

ABAP Code:

lv_json_body =
'{' &&
'"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
'"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
'"category":"Data",' &&
'"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
'"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"impact":"2",' &&
'"urgency":"2"' &&
'}'.

Step 3: Create the Incident via POST API

Now, make a POST request to the ServiceNow incident table, including your access token for authorization.

ABAP Code:

FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, cv_result will contain the incident response from ServiceNow.

Step 4: Combine the Steps in Your Report

Your main program calls these subroutines in sequence.

Example Main Logic:

* Get the access token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token
               USING lv_token_url
                     lv_client_id
                     lv_client_secret
               CHANGING ls_token
                     lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Create the incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident
                    USING lv_post_url
                          ls_token-access_token
                          lv_json_body
                   CHANGING lv_result
                            lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.

Final Notes

  • Security: Never hardcode sensitive data in productive programsâ€”use secure storage.
  • Error Handling: Always add robust error handling and log failures for troubleshooting.
  • Data Mapping: Adjust JSON fields based on ServiceNow table and your organizationâ€™s requirements.

Conclusion

Integrating SAP and ServiceNow allows you to automatically manage ITSM incidents directly from SAP ABAP.  The above example demonstrates OAuth token retrieval and incident creation using ABAP.  Adapt and build on this foundation to suit your business requirements.

Happy Integrating! Let me know in the comments if you have any questions or need clarification on any step.

 

Complete ABAP CODE:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZSNOW
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Utility: ServiceNow Incident API Integration
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*

REPORT zsnow.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_token,
         access_token TYPE string,
         scope        TYPE string,
         token_type   TYPE string,
         expires_in   TYPE i,
       END OF ty_token.

DATA: lv_token_url     TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/oauth_token',
      lv_client_id     TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-id...',
      lv_client_secret TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-secret...',
      lv_post_url      TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/api/now/table/incident',
      lv_json_body     TYPE string,
      ls_token         TYPE ty_token,
      lv_err           TYPE string,
      lv_result        TYPE string.

* Prepare JSON Body

lv_json_body = '{' &&
               '"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
               '"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
               '"category":"Data",' &&
               '"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
               '"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"impact":"2",' &&
               '"urgency":"2"' &&
               '}'.

* Step 1: Get the Token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token USING lv_token_url
                                   lv_client_id
                                   lv_client_secret
                          CHANGING ls_token
                                   lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Step 2: Create Incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident USING lv_post_url
                                         ls_token-access_token
                                         lv_json_body
                                CHANGING lv_result
                                         lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.



*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Get OAuth Token from ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM get_servicenow_token
  USING    iv_token_url TYPE string
           iv_client_id TYPE string
           iv_client_secret TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " get_servicenow_token

*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Create an Incident in ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " create_servicenow_incident

entry.title: SAPâ€™s Engagement in the Eclipse IDE Working Group
entry.content:
Since 2021, SAP has been a founding member of the Eclipse IDE Working Group. It was established to ensure the long-term sustainability, integrity, and evolution of Eclipse IDE products. SAP's ABAP Development Tools (ADT) are powered by the robust Eclipse platform, allowing us to leverage its extensive capabilities and flexibility. This strategic choice enables us to innovate rapidly and deliver high-quality solutions. By actively contributing and collaborating, we help shape the platform's future, mitigate potential risks, and guarantee the availability and continuous improvement of the tools our users rely on. This is currently driven by five employees with committer status.

In this article, we would like to reflect on how we were involved with the Eclipse community on behalf of SAP and the Eclipse IDE Working Group.

Looking Back On 2025

This year was a continuation of our collaboration with the Eclipse IDE community. Beyond code contributions, SAP actively participated in various events and initiatives to support and grow the Eclipse community. Key highlights have been:

  • Eclipse shipped four releases of the Desktop IDE and we are proud that some of SAPâ€™s contributions are listed as new and noteworthy changes in the release notes.
  • SAP hosted Eclipse Platform RCP & IDE Open Community Meetups in Germany and India, giving developers, contributors, and enthusiasts a chance to connect. We covered a wide range of topics - from community updates and progress on modernizing the Eclipse UI Toolkit to improvements on performance, security, and user experience. The agenda also included demos from Eclipse Platform committers and SAP experts about new Java features and the IBM Semuru releases, practical Eclipse IDE tips, showcases of AI features in Eclipse-based products, and sessions on improving the contributor experience. Beyond the sessions, informal discussions sparked fresh ideas, proving that open source thrives through shared effort and engagement.
    Meetup in Germany, July 2025

    Meetup in India, September 2025

  • Regular engagement in the IDE working group lead to a very productive collaboration with different working group companies and other project committers, making it possible to contribute major changes such as UI modernizations.
  • To strengthen our commitment and contribution to the Eclipse IDE ecosystem, we upgraded our membership level from "Strategic Member" to the Platinum-level of the Eclipse Foundationâ€™s IDE Working Group in 2025.
  • Sonja LiÃ©nard (@lienards), Head of ABAP Platform and true ABAP expert, was interviewed in SAPâ€™s podcast "The Open Source Way", sharing insights into SAPâ€™s history of the ABAP programming language and some open source fun facts, such as even Visual Studio Code using Eclipse for the Java language support. She goes into quite some details on how SAP leverages the Eclipse IDE to provide a comprehensive and flexible development environment for its technologies. Listen to the episode at https://podcast.opensap.info/open-source-way/2025/12/01/abap-and-eclipse/. 

With these activities we aimed to give our share to collaboration and continuous investment to ensure the sustainable evolution and long-term availability of the Eclipse IDE.

Looking Ahead to 2026

Building on this strong momentum, we are looking forward to continuing our open source journey with the community to propel Eclipse forward. In 2026, we also plan to host Open Community Meetups again, providing opportunities to exchange ideas, showcase progress, and strengthen connections across the ecosystem.

Saying Thank You

A big THANKS to all colleagues, community members, and contributors who make Eclipse what it is. Every idea, contribution, and discussion helping keep the platform thriving for years to come.

Letâ€™s keep Eclipse thriving â€“ together!

entry.title: Extract Rev-Trac requests by custom program and Rev-Trac API
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • What is the Rev-Trac API?
  • Rev-Trac RFC destination
  • /RSC/API_GET_REQUESTS
  • Program to extract the custom long text fields of requests
  • Table ZRSC_REQ_COPY
  • ABAP Code

 

Introduction

In this post, I propose a program to do a full-text search in custom long text field(s) of Rev-Trac requests stored on a central Rev-Trac system, by RFC. For searching fast, the program stores the data in a custom table and refreshes it by querying the last changed requests (delta mode). This post also helps developers to find and call remotely Rev-Trac API function modules. I also created this post because there are very few resources talking about custom development with Rev-Trac.

Rev-Trac is a software to manage SAP Change Requests, all SAP Transport Requests which belong to one feature are assigned to one Rev-Trac request and there are controls to make sure that there's no conflict with other features when delivering the feature (a little bit like SAP ChaRM).

Rev-Trac is installed both in a central system which contains all Rev-Trac data, and in all the ABAP systems where the SAP transport requests are located, which connect to the central system via RFC.

I'm using an old Rev-Trac version ("Rev-Trac Master API version: 7.2.0" via the transaction code /RSC/RT > menu Administration > Rev-Trac version) so maybe this program cannot be used on the latest versions (as far as I can see, right now the last version is around 8.3.6).

About the context:

  • My current client has interfaced Rev-Trac with a Project Management system (EasyVista Service Manager, which is a software alike Atlassian Jira, ServiceNow, Tricentis and others).
  • Rev-Trac requests have custom text fields which are filled manually to store the ticket numbers of EV Service Manager. For information, long text custom fields were configured in the transaction code /RSC/CF42, appended to the table /RSC/T_RM_3H, a custom screen was created to contain these fields, and its screen number was set by implementing the function module exit /RSC/EI_CUSTOMER_EXIT_016 to add it to the "Additional fields" tab of the Rev-Trac requests screen.
    • For information, if you want to know where the user exits are called, display the where-used list of the function module /RSC/CE_GET_CUSTOMER_EXIT_NAME.
  • As far as I can see, there is no feature to do a full-text search in the custom text fields, so I created a custom program in another system to query the text fields, as I have no authorization to develop in the central system.
  • The program was created on an ABAP 7.40 SP 23 system.
  • NB: if you want more information about Rev-Trac, it's a software by Revelation Software Concepts https://revelationsoftwareconcepts.com/. Its specific Web site is https://rev-trac.com/. There's also a documentation at Rev-Trac User Guides Home - Rev-Trac Resources - Confluence. NB: in case you ask, I'm not affiliated to RSC and Rev-Trac in any way.

 

What is the Rev-Trac API?

The Rev-Trac API 7.2.0 is based on RFC-enabled function modules which are prefixed /RSC/API_ and belong to the package /RSC/DEV_API.

These function modules may be called from another ABAP system by using an RFC destination described in the next chapter.

Examples of API:

  • /RSC/API_CREATE_RT_REQUEST
  • /RSC/API_GET_REQUESTS
  • /RSC/API_UPDATE_RT_REQUEST
  • /RSC/API_UPDATE_RT_STATUS
  • /RSC/API_GET_MASTER_RFC_DEST

There is a convention for the parameter names:

  • They are prefixed "P"
  • The second character can be:
    • "S": structure
    • "W": simple field
    • "T": table
      • They are always passed through TABLES parameters.
  • The third character indicates if the parameter is to be input or output, which is especially useful for TABLES parameters:
    • "I": input parameter
    • "E": output parameter

The read API have boolean parameters used to indicate which kind of data you want to retrieve (none by default).

The update API insert, update or delete the table data directly without sending to the SAP update task and they don't commit explicitly. Either you call BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT explicitly or a database commit is done implicitly when the RFC connection ends (or rollback if it fails).

 

Rev-Trac RFC destination

Before calling a Rev-Trac function module, the RFC destination must be queried. In all the systems which connect to the central Rev-Trac system, the table /RSC/T_CEM_PARMS contains one line (SYSID = current system and PARM = "MASTER") which indicates what the central system is. The Rev-Trac RFC destination names are prefixed "Y/RSC/RFC".

This RFC destination may be obtained by calling the function module /RSC/API_GET_MASTER_RFC_DEST:

    DATA rfc_destination TYPE rfcdest.
    CALL FUNCTION '/RSC/API_GET_MASTER_RFC_DEST'
      EXPORTING
        pwi_dialog      = 'X'
        pwi_prefer_none = 'X'
      IMPORTING
        pwe_dest        = rfc_destination
      EXCEPTIONS
        not_found       = 1
        OTHERS          = 2.

 

/RSC/API_GET_REQUESTS

This function module is used to query the Rev-Trac requests to obtain all information. If you only need the main fields like the text or the last modification date, you may use /RSC/API_SEARCH_REQUESTS.

The following parameters are used by the custom program:

  • PWI_GET_REQUEST_DETAILS: boolean to retrieve the values of the main fields like the last modification date
  • PWI_GET_CUSTOM_LONG: boolean to retrieve the values of the custom long text fields
  • PTI_FILTER_MDATE: filter the requests by the last modification date
  • PTE_REQUEST_DETAILS: main fields like the last modification date
  • PTE_CUSTOM_LONG: values of the custom long text fields

 

Program to extract the custom long text fields of requests

First of all, a custom table must be created to allow a fast search (except the first time, it must be filled completely). The program will query the requests changed recently, store the data in this custom table and query it.

Table ZRSC_REQ_COPY

define table zrsc_req_copy {
key mandt: mandt not null;
key req: /rsc/req not null;
    mdate: /rsc/mdate;
    zzfield_1_len: /rsc/lcharlen;
    zzfield_1: /rsc/customlongtext;
    zzfield_2_len: /rsc/lcharlen;
    zzfield_2: /rsc/customlongtext;
}

 

ABAP Code

REPORT zindex_revtrac.

PARAMETERS p_req TYPE /rsc/req NO-DISPLAY.
PARAMETERS p_search TYPE c LENGTH 9 OBLIGATORY.

CLASS lcl_app DEFINITION DEFERRED.
DATA go_app TYPE REF TO lcl_app.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  CREATE OBJECT go_app TYPE ('LCL_APP').
  CALL METHOD go_app->('MAIN').
  ASSERT 1 = 1. " debug helper

CLASS lcl_app DEFINITION.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    METHODS main.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    TYPES:
      BEGIN OF ts_tq_excerpt,
        trkorr TYPE tmsbuffer-trkorr,
      END OF ts_tq_excerpt.
    TYPES tt_buffer TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tmsbuffer WITH DEFAULT KEY.

    METHODS search_rt.

ENDCLASS.


CLASS lcl_rev_trac_api DEFINITION.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    TYPES tt_filter_req         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_proj        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_rtype       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_class       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_team        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_status      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_cdate       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_mdate       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_textu       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_module      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_ustat       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_relse       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_kwords      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_userid      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_sevr        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_pri         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_filter_saprl       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_api_001 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_requests           TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_rm_3_23 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_request_details    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/t_rm_3a WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_custom_fields      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/t_rm_3h WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_custom_long        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/t_rm_3hl WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_history_log        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_ce_0_107 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_spec_mig_ins       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_ce_0_107 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_attachments        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_bd_2_04 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_reference_list     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_ce_0_108 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_reference_details  TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_rm_3_24 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_dynamic_links      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_ce_0_109 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_xd_package_details TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_xd_0_02 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_abap_components    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_mf_4_34 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_xd_dependencies    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_dp_0_07 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_msg_header         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_rm_3_15 WITH DEFAULT KEY.
    TYPES tt_msg_items          TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF /rsc/s_rm_3_16 WITH DEFAULT KEY.

    TYPES: BEGIN OF ts_get_requests,
             BEGIN OF import,
               pwi_get_request_details     TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_custom_fields       TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_custom_long         TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_history_log         TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_spec_mig_ins        TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_attachments         TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_ref_list            TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_rererence_details   TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_dynamic_links       TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_tx_list             TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_abap_components     TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_xd_list             TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_xd_details          TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_xd_depd             TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_non_abap_components TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_get_approvals           TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_uname                   TYPE /rsc/syuname,
               pwi_filter_smi              TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_owner            TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_programmer       TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_customizer       TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_actor            TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_standin          TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_signer           TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_last_modifier    TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pwi_filter_creator          TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pti_filter_req              TYPE tt_filter_req,
               pti_filter_proj             TYPE tt_filter_proj,
               pti_filter_rtype            TYPE tt_filter_rtype,
               pti_filter_class            TYPE tt_filter_class,
               pti_filter_team             TYPE tt_filter_team,
               pti_filter_status           TYPE tt_filter_status,
               pti_filter_cdate            TYPE tt_filter_cdate,
               pti_filter_mdate            TYPE tt_filter_mdate,
               pti_filter_textu            TYPE tt_filter_textu,
               pti_filter_module           TYPE tt_filter_module,
               pti_filter_ustat            TYPE tt_filter_ustat,
               pti_filter_relse            TYPE tt_filter_relse,
               pti_filter_kwords           TYPE tt_filter_kwords,
               pti_filter_userid           TYPE tt_filter_userid,
               pti_filter_sevr             TYPE tt_filter_sevr,
               pti_filter_pri              TYPE tt_filter_pri,
               pti_filter_saprl            TYPE tt_filter_saprl,
             END OF import,
             BEGIN OF export,
               pte_non_abap_components TYPE /rsc/tt_mf_005,
               "! Filled only if PWI_GET_TX_LIST = 'X'
               pte_transports          TYPE /rsc/tt_mf_007,
               pte_xd_list             TYPE /rsc/tt_xd_004,
               pte_approvals           TYPE /rsc/tt_rm_003,
               pwe_date_stamp          TYPE /rsc/sydatum,
               pwe_time_stamp          TYPE /rsc/syuzeit,
               pwe_result              TYPE /rsc/flag,
               pte_requests            TYPE tt_requests,
               pte_request_details     TYPE tt_request_details,
               pte_custom_fields       TYPE tt_custom_fields,
               pte_custom_long         TYPE tt_custom_long,
               pte_history_log         TYPE tt_history_log,
               pte_spec_mig_ins        TYPE tt_spec_mig_ins,
               pte_attachments         TYPE tt_attachments,
               pte_reference_list      TYPE tt_reference_list,
               pte_reference_details   TYPE tt_reference_details,
               pte_dynamic_links       TYPE tt_dynamic_links,
               pte_xd_package_details  TYPE tt_xd_package_details,
               pte_abap_components     TYPE tt_abap_components,
               pte_xd_dependencies     TYPE tt_xd_dependencies,
               pte_msg_header          TYPE tt_msg_header,
               pte_msg_items           TYPE tt_msg_items,
             END OF export,
           END OF ts_get_requests.

    CLASS-METHODS api_get_requests
      IMPORTING VALUE(import) TYPE ts_get_requests-import
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE ts_get_requests-export.

    CLASS-METHODS class_constructor.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    CLASS-DATA w_rfcdest TYPE /rsc/s_cem_0_10-rfcdest.

ENDCLASS.


CLASS ltc_main DEFINITION
  FOR TESTING RISK LEVEL HARMLESS DURATION SHORT.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS test FOR TESTING.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS ltc_main IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD test.
    DATA requests_2 TYPE lcl_rev_trac_api=>ts_get_requests-export ##NEEDED.

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>fail( msg   = 'FOR DEBUG ONLY'
                               level = if_aunit_constants=>tolerable ).
    requests_2 = lcl_rev_trac_api=>api_get_requests(
                     import = VALUE #( pwi_get_request_details     = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_custom_fields       = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_custom_long         = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_history_log         = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_spec_mig_ins        = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_attachments         = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_ref_list            = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_rererence_details   = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_dynamic_links       = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_tx_list             = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_abap_components     = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_xd_list             = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_xd_details          = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_xd_depd             = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_non_abap_components = abap_true
                                       pwi_get_approvals           = abap_true
*                                       pwi_get_tx_list             = 'X'
*                                       pwi_get_request_details     = 'X'
                                       pti_filter_req              = VALUE #( ( low = '0000004116' ) )
*                                       pti_filter_mdate            = VALUE #( ( low = '20241007' ) )
                                       ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS lcl_app IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD main.
    IF p_search IS NOT INITIAL.
      search_rt( ).
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD search_rt.
    TYPES tt_zrsc_req_copy TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zrsc_req_copy WITH EMPTY KEY.

    SELECT MAX( mdate ) FROM zrsc_req_copy INTO (max_mdate).
    DATA(requests) = lcl_rev_trac_api=>api_get_requests(
                         VALUE #( pwi_get_request_details = 'X'
                                  pwi_get_custom_long     = 'X'
                                  pti_filter_mdate        = VALUE #( ( low = max_mdate high = sy-datum ) ) ) ).
    DATA(lt_zrsc_req_copy) = VALUE tt_zrsc_req_copy(
        FOR GROUPS <group_by_request> OF <custom_long> IN requests-pte_custom_long
        GROUP BY ( request = <custom_long>-request )
        LET table_temp_custom_long = VALUE lcl_rev_trac_api=>TT_custom_long( for <temp_custom_long> in group <group_by_request>
                                          ( <temp_custom_long> ) )
            zzfield_1 = table_temp_custom_long[ fieldname = 'ZZFIELD_1' ]-long_text
            zzfield_2 = table_temp_custom_long[ fieldname = 'ZZFIELD_2' ]-long_text
        IN
        ( req           = <group_by_request>-request
          mdate         = VALUE #( requests-pte_request_details[ request = <group_by_request>-request ]-mdate OPTIONAL )
          zzfield_1_len = strlen( zzfield_1 )
          zzfield_1     = zzfield_1
          zzfield_2_len = strlen( zzfield_2 )
          zzfield_2     = zzfield_2 ) ).
    MODIFY zrsc_req_copy FROM TABLE lt_zrsc_req_copy.
    COMMIT WORK.
    FREE lt_zrsc_req_copy.

    " NB: with ABAP SQL, impossible to filter LCHR columns via WHERE.
    SELECT *
      FROM zrsc_req_copy
      INTO TABLE _zrsc_req_copy.

    " Filter in ABAP
    DATA(filter) = |*{ p_search }*|.
    DELETE lt_zrsc_req_copy WHERE zzfield_1 NP filter.

    requests = lcl_rev_trac_api=>api_get_requests(
                   VALUE #( pwi_get_request_details = 'X'
                            pti_filter_req          = VALUE #( FOR <ls_zrsc_req_copy> IN lt_zrsc_req_copy
                                                               ( low = <ls_zrsc_req_copy>-req ) ) ) ).
    LOOP AT lt_zrsc_req_copy REFERENCE INTO DATA(ls_zrsc_req_copy).
      DATA(ls_pte_request_detail) = REF #( requests-pte_request_details[ request = ls_zrsc_req_copy->req ] ).
      WRITE : / ls_zrsc_req_copy->req,
                ls_pte_request_detail->text.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS lcl_rev_trac_api IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD api_get_requests.
    CALL FUNCTION '/RSC/API_GET_REQUESTS'
      DESTINATION w_rfcdest
      EXPORTING
        pwi_get_request_details     = import-pwi_get_request_details
        pwi_get_custom_fields       = import-pwi_get_custom_fields
        pwi_get_custom_long         = import-pwi_get_custom_long
        pwi_get_history_log         = import-pwi_get_history_log
        pwi_get_spec_mig_ins        = import-pwi_get_spec_mig_ins
        pwi_get_attachments         = import-pwi_get_attachments
        pwi_get_ref_list            = import-pwi_get_ref_list
        pwi_get_rererence_details   = import-pwi_get_rererence_details
        pwi_get_dynamic_links       = import-pwi_get_dynamic_links
        pwi_get_tx_list             = import-pwi_get_tx_list
        pwi_get_abap_components     = import-pwi_get_abap_components
        pwi_get_xd_list             = import-pwi_get_xd_list
        pwi_get_xd_details          = import-pwi_get_xd_details
        pwi_get_xd_depd             = import-pwi_get_xd_depd
        pwi_get_non_abap_components = import-pwi_get_non_abap_components
        pwi_get_approvals           = import-pwi_get_approvals
        pwi_uname                   = import-pwi_uname
        pwi_filter_smi              = import-pwi_filter_smi
        pwi_filter_owner            = import-pwi_filter_owner
        pwi_filter_programmer       = import-pwi_filter_programmer
        pwi_filter_customizer       = import-pwi_filter_customizer
        pwi_filter_actor            = import-pwi_filter_actor
        pwi_filter_standin          = import-pwi_filter_standin
        pwi_filter_signer           = import-pwi_filter_signer
        pwi_filter_last_modifier    = import-pwi_filter_last_modifier
        pwi_filter_creator          = import-pwi_filter_creator
      IMPORTING
        pte_non_abap_components     = result-pte_non_abap_components
        pte_transports              = result-pte_transports
        pte_xd_list                 = result-pte_xd_list
        pte_approvals               = result-pte_approvals
        pwe_date_stamp              = result-pwe_date_stamp
        pwe_time_stamp              = result-pwe_time_stamp
      TABLES
        pti_filter_req              = import-pti_filter_req
        pti_filter_proj             = import-pti_filter_proj
        pti_filter_rtype            = import-pti_filter_rtype
        pti_filter_class            = import-pti_filter_class
        pti_filter_team             = import-pti_filter_team
        pti_filter_status           = import-pti_filter_status
        pti_filter_cdate            = import-pti_filter_cdate
        pti_filter_mdate            = import-pti_filter_mdate
        pti_filter_textu            = import-pti_filter_textu
        pti_filter_module           = import-pti_filter_module
        pti_filter_ustat            = import-pti_filter_ustat
        pti_filter_relse            = import-pti_filter_relse
        pti_filter_kwords           = import-pti_filter_kwords
        pti_filter_userid           = import-pti_filter_userid
        pti_filter_sevr             = import-pti_filter_sevr
        pti_filter_pri              = import-pti_filter_pri
        pti_filter_saprl            = import-pti_filter_saprl
        pte_requests                = result-pte_requests
        pte_request_details         = result-pte_request_details
        pte_custom_fields           = result-pte_custom_fields
        pte_custom_long             = result-pte_custom_long
        pte_history_log             = result-pte_history_log
        pte_spec_mig_ins            = result-pte_spec_mig_ins
        pte_attachments             = result-pte_attachments
        pte_reference_list          = result-pte_reference_list
        pte_reference_details       = result-pte_reference_details
        pte_dynamic_links           = result-pte_dynamic_links
        pte_xd_package_details      = result-pte_xd_package_details
        pte_abap_components         = result-pte_abap_components
        pte_xd_dependencies         = result-pte_xd_dependencies
        pte_msg_header              = result-pte_msg_header
        pte_msg_items               = result-pte_msg_items.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD class_constructor.
    CALL FUNCTION '/RSC/API_GET_MASTER_RFC_DEST'
      EXPORTING
        pwi_dialog      = 'X'
        pwi_prefer_none = 'X'
      IMPORTING
        pwe_dest        = w_rfcdest
      EXCEPTIONS
        not_found       = 1
        OTHERS          = 2.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

 

Thank you. Feel free to comment and post your own blog about Rev-Trac API.

Sandra

entry.title: Small program to test the SCSM_NW_WORKLOAD interface for reading ABAP statistics data
entry.content:
The "SCSM_NW_WORKLOAD interface" corresponds to the SAP note 1053634 - SCSM_NW_WORKLOAD interface for reading ABAP statistics data - SAP for Me. In fact, it's the name of the function group containing the function modules which can be called to read the ABAP statistics data (data displayed by the transaction codes ST03, ST03N, STAT).

There are very few code snippets about these function modules, so I decided to publish a little test program which calls these function modules. This program is useful in debug to find out how the ABAP statistics data are structured, to build your own program with the data you need.

The program calls the following RFC-enabled function modules:

  • SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME
  • SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME
  • SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME
  • SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME

It calls SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME and SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME to read the whole aggregated data (total and by server).

It calls SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME and SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME to read the detailed records of ABAP statistics data of the last 3 days, with a time frame of 60 minutes (these filter and setting can be changed).

I used this program in an ABAP 7.40 SP 23 system.

Happy coding and feel free to publish your own code snippets!

Sandra

REPORT z_read_st03n_data.
* Note 1053634:
* With the SAP upgrade to SAP_BASIS 7.0(NW 2004s), both the methods and
* the corresponding function modules for reading ABAP statistics data
* have changed. The SAPWL_GLOB_STAT function group can no longer be
* used as of SAP_BASIS 7.0.
* (SAPWL_GLOB_STAT = SAPWL_STATREC_FROM_REMOTE_SYS, etc.)
* The new function group includes the following four function modules:
* - SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME
* - SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME
* - SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME
* - SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME
DATA(select_from_systems) = VALUE swncgl_t_dest( ).
DATA(all_directories)  = VALUE swncgl_t_alldir( ).
DATA(protocol_allrcinf) = VALUE swncgl_t_allrcinf( ).

select_from_systems = VALUE #(
  ( select_system  = sy-sysid
*    select_servers =
) ).
CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME'
  EXPORTING
    select_from_systems = select_from_systems "sy-sysid
  IMPORTING
    all_directories     = all_directories
    protocol            = protocol_allrcinf.

DATA(select_system) = VALUE swncsysdest( ).
DATA(systemid) = VALUE swncsysid( ).
DATA(instance) = VALUE swnchostname( ).
DATA(periodtype) = VALUE swncperitype( ).
DATA(periodstrt) = VALUE swncdatum( ).
DATA(summary_only) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(tasktype) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtasktype( ).
DATA(tasktimes) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtasktimes( ).
DATA(times) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtimes( ).
DATA(dbprocs) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggdbprocs( ).
DATA(extsystem) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggextsystem( ).
DATA(tcdet) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtcdet( ).
DATA(frontend) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggfrontend( ).
DATA(memory) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggmemory( ).
DATA(spool) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggspool( ).
DATA(spoolact) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggspoolact( ).
DATA(tablerec) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtablerec( ).
DATA(usertcode) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggusertcode( ).
DATA(userworkload) = VALUE swncgl_t_agguserworkload( ).
DATA(rfcclnt) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcclnt( ).
DATA(rfcclntdest) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcclntdest( ).
DATA(rfcsrvr) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcsrvr( ).
DATA(rfcsrvrdest) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcsrvrdest( ).
DATA(astat) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggappstat( ).
DATA(hitlist_database) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlist( ).
DATA(hitlist_resptime) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlist( ).
DATA(hitlist_astat_db) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).
DATA(hitlist_astat_resptime) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).
DATA(comp_hierarchy) = VALUE swncgl_t_comphiertxt( ).
DATA(org_units) = VALUE swncgl_t_orgunit( ).
DATA(dbcon) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggdbc( ).
DATA(webc) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebclnt( ).
DATA(webcd) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebdest( ).
DATA(webs) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebclnt( ).
DATA(websd) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebdest( ).
DATA(vmc) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggvmc( ).
DATA(protocol_rcinf) = VALUE swncgl_t_rcinf( ).
DATA(trex) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtrex( ).

LOOP AT all_directories REFERENCE INTO DATA(directory).
  summary_only = abap_false.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME'
    EXPORTING
*      select_system          = " RFC destination?
      systemid               = directory->assigndsys
      instance               = directory->component
      periodtype             = directory->periodtype
      periodstrt             = directory->periodstrt
      summary_only           = summary_only
    IMPORTING
      tasktype               = tasktype
      tasktimes              = tasktimes
      times                  = times
      dbprocs                = dbprocs
      extsystem              = extsystem
      tcdet                  = tcdet
      frontend               = frontend
      memory                 = memory
      spool                  = spool
      spoolact               = spoolact
      tablerec               = tablerec
      usertcode              = usertcode
      userworkload           = userworkload
      rfcclnt                = rfcclnt
      rfcclntdest            = rfcclntdest
      rfcsrvr                = rfcsrvr
      rfcsrvrdest            = rfcsrvrdest
      astat                  = astat
      hitlist_database       = hitlist_database
      hitlist_resptime       = hitlist_resptime
      hitlist_astat_db       = hitlist_astat_db
      hitlist_astat_resptime = hitlist_astat_resptime
      comp_hierarchy         = comp_hierarchy
      org_units              = org_units
      dbcon                  = dbcon
      webc                   = webc
      webcd                  = webcd
      webs                   = webs
      websd                  = websd
      vmc                    = vmc
      protocol               = protocol_rcinf
      trex                   = trex.
  ASSERT 1 = 1. " debug helper
ENDLOOP.

DATA(read_start_date) = VALUE swncdatum( ).
DATA(read_start_time) = VALUE swncuzeit( ).
DATA(read_end_date) = VALUE swncdatum( ).
DATA(read_end_time) = VALUE swncuzeit( ).
DATA(read_time_zone) = VALUE swnctimezone( ).
DATA(read_client) = VALUE swncmandt( ).
DATA(read_username) = VALUE swncuname( ).
DATA(flag_exclude_username) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(read_transids) = VALUE swncgl_t_transid( ).
DATA(read_workprocess) = VALUE swncrshrt( ).
DATA(read_only_mainrecords) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(read_stat) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(read_astat) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(wait_seconds) = VALUE i( ).
DATA(max_records) = VALUE swncrecs( ).
DATA(get_comp_hierarchy) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(get_org_units) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(all_statrecs) = VALUE swncgl_t_allrecs( ).
DATA(protocol) = VALUE swncgl_t_allrcinf( ).
DATA(ext_esi_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_esirecs( ).
DATA(ext_passport_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_passportrecs( ).
DATA(webservice_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_webservicerecs( ).
DATA(trex_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_trexrecs( ).

read_start_date = sy-datum - 3.
read_start_time = '000000'.
read_end_date = sy-datum.
read_end_time = sy-uzeit.
read_stat = abap_true.
*read_astat = abap_true.
max_records = -1.

data(time_resolution) = value swnctimeres( ).
data(tasktypes_per_workprocess) = value swnc_cflag( ).
data(tcodes_with_dynpro_number) = value swnc_cflag( ).
data(terminal_instead_of_username) = value swnc_cflag( ).
data(ashitl_database) = value swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).
data(ashitl_resptime) = value swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).

time_resolution = 60. "60 minutes

call function 'SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME'
  EXPORTING
*    select_system                = SPACE
*    select_server                =
*    read_time_zone               =
    read_start_date              = read_start_date
    read_start_time              = read_start_time
    read_end_date                = read_end_date
    read_end_time                = read_end_time
    read_client                  = read_client
    read_username                = read_username
    read_workprocess             = read_workprocess
    read_stat                    = read_stat
    read_astat                   = read_astat
    wait_seconds                 = wait_seconds
    time_resolution              = time_resolution
    tasktypes_per_workprocess    = tasktypes_per_workprocess
    tcodes_with_dynpro_number    = tcodes_with_dynpro_number
    terminal_instead_of_username = terminal_instead_of_username
    max_records                  = max_records
  IMPORTING
    tasktype                     = tasktype
    tasktimes                    = tasktimes
    times                        = times
    dbprocs                      = dbprocs
    extsystem                    = extsystem
    tcdet                        = tcdet
    frontend                     = frontend
    memory                       = memory
    spool                        = spool
    spoolact                     = spoolact
    tablerec                     = tablerec
    usertcode                    = usertcode
    userworkload                 = userworkload
    rfcclnt                      = rfcclnt
    rfcclntdest                  = rfcclntdest
    rfcsrvr                      = rfcsrvr
    rfcsrvrdest                  = rfcsrvrdest
    astat                        = astat
    hitlist_database             = hitlist_database
    hitlist_resptime             = hitlist_resptime
    ashitl_database              = ashitl_database
    ashitl_resptime              = ashitl_resptime
    comp_hierarchy               = comp_hierarchy
    org_units                    = org_units
    dbcon                        = dbcon
    webc                         = webc
    webcd                        = webcd
    webs                         = webs
    websd                        = websd
    vmc                          = vmc
    protocol                     = protocol.

CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME'
  EXPORTING
    select_from_systems   = select_from_systems
    read_start_date       = read_start_date
    read_start_time       = read_start_time
    read_end_date         = read_end_date
    read_end_time         = read_end_time
    read_time_zone        = read_time_zone
    read_client           = read_client
    read_username         = read_username
    flag_exclude_username = flag_exclude_username
    read_transids         = read_transids
    read_workprocess      = read_workprocess
    read_only_mainrecords = read_only_mainrecords
    read_stat             = read_stat
    read_astat            = read_astat
    wait_seconds          = wait_seconds
    max_records           = max_records
    get_comp_hierarchy    = get_comp_hierarchy
    get_org_units         = get_org_units
  IMPORTING
    all_statrecs          = all_statrecs
    protocol              = protocol
    ext_esi_records       = ext_esi_records
    ext_passport_records  = ext_passport_records
    webservice_records    = webservice_records
    trex_records          = trex_records.

LOOP AT all_statrecs REFERENCE INTO DATA(statrecs).
  LOOP AT statrecs->statrecs REFERENCE INTO DATA(statrec)
      WHERE mainrec-tcode IS NOT INITIAL.
    WRITE: / statrec->mainrec-account, statrec->mainrec-starttimestamp, statrec->mainrec-tcode.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDLOOP.
ASSERT 1 = 1. " debug helper

entry.title: Sharing our custom copy programs based on read and create BAPI
entry.content:
This blog post is a little call to the community to share code snippets of "copy programs" for BAPI business objects. I explain the concept, how to create such a program, and propose one example.

It may be a little bit difficult to develop a program from scratch for creating a Business Object (*) by calling a create BAPI function module:

  1. Pass the right values to make the BAPI succeed (consistent values, fields to be entered either in internal or in external format, etc.)
  2. Use of additional function modules (for long texts, to cleanup memory or special commit, BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT and ROLLBACK)
  3. Special technical parameters for some BAPI
  4. Custom fields via the EXTENSIONIN parameter

That would be much easier if there was a copy program provided to create a business object via BAPI from an existing business object:

  1. Ask the functional team or end user to create manually the expected business object(s)
  2. Run the copy program to copy the business object
  3. Debug the copy program to see the values passed to the create BAPI
  4. Now it should be easier to create the custom program as per the requirements

Again, the goal of the custom program is not to copy a template business object in the production system, but to create a business object from scratch according to some client requirements; the goal of the copy program is to help developing this custom program.

The easiest way to create a copy program is to call the read BAPI to get all the business object details and pass them to the create BAPI, because the parameters are usually very similar. When they differ, usually only a small conversion logic is needed.

Here's one example of what could be such a copy program, applied to the business object BUS2172 (projects in the SAP Portfolio and Project Management module - PPM). The BAPI used by this copy program are BAPI_BUS2172_GET_DETAIL and BAPI_BUS2172_CREATE. For information, this business object is mainly stored in the table DPR_PROJECT; it can be created and maintained via the Web Dynpro application INM_WORKCENTER_APP (with the URL query ?iv_appl_type=DPO&iv_context=WS&iv_obj_type_r=DPO&iv_portal_role=DPR_PROJECT&sap-client=...)

To fill the parameters of the create BAPI, the easiest way is to call the "read" BAPI (BAPI_BUS2172_GET_DETAIL) because the parameters are usually very similar.

The read and create BAPI parameters may differ, so the parameters must be converted. For BUS2172, they differ on these points:

  • The read BAPI may return the project name in different languages in an internal table while the create BAPI has only one name in the language defined in the component PROJECT_DESCRIPTION_NAME of the parameter IS_PROJECT_DEFINITION
  • Same thing for the project description. Also, the read BAPI may return the description as a table of text lines while the create BAPI has 4 binary components. It's explained below how to convert it.
  • The read BAPI returns the dates in external format while the create BAPI expects the dates in internal format

BAPI_BUS2172_CREATE has several specificities (which are documented in the function module documentation):

  • Commit is to be done via BAPI_CPROJECTS_COMMIT_WORK and rollback via BAPI_CPROJECTS_ROLLBACK_WORK
  • The technical parameter IS_PROJECT_DEFINITION_UPD is a structure with components to be set with "X" values for all the fields to initialize by the values in the parameter IS_PROJECT_DEFINITION.
  • The components PROJECT_DESCRIPTION_PARTX (X = 1 to 4) components of the parameter IS_PROJECT_DEFINITION are binary fields with a total length of 1020 bytes which must be initialized from a text via the method CL_DPR_BAPI_SERVICES=>CONVERT_STRING_TO_RAWPARTS (UTF-8 with the last bytes to be spaces).

This copy program should work in all projects. Don't add anything custom when you share it.

Now we can run this copy program.

After making sure the copy program has created the business object, the parameters passed to BAPI_BUS2172_CREATE can be carefully analyzed by debug:

Now, the custom program may be created (manually) with the required logic to reproduce the same parameter values (at least for the first test run).

That would be great if people can share such copy programs because they are easy to create, they are useful and they don't contain any confidential information.

Thanks a lot for reading me!

Sandra

Here's the code of the copy program for BUS2172 (note that it's currently limited because it doesn't copy the project elements like the phases, tasks, checklist headers and items, which correspond respectively to the business object types BUS2173, BUS2175, BUS2176 and BUS2174). It works in an ABAP 7.40 system:

REPORT z_bus2172_copy_program.

PARAMETERS projguid TYPE bapi_ts_guid-project_definition_guid.
PARAMETERS projnum TYPE dpr_project-project_id.

CLASS lcl_app DEFINITION DEFERRED.

DATA go_app TYPE REF TO lcl_app.

LOAD-OF-PROGRAM.
  CALL METHOD lcl_app=>('CREATE')
    RECEIVING
      result = go_app.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  CALL METHOD go_app->('START_OF_SELECTION').

CLASS lcl_app DEFINITION FINAL
  CREATE PRIVATE.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS class_constructor.

    CLASS-METHODS create
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO lcl_app.

    METHODS start_of_selection.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    CLASS-DATA initial_external_date TYPE bapi_date.

    CLASS-METHODS conv_date_ext_to_int
      IMPORTING iv_date_format_externe_courant TYPE csequence
      RETURNING VALUE(result)                  TYPE d.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS lcl_app IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD class_constructor.
    DATA(d) = VALUE d( ).
    WRITE d TO initial_external_date.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD conv_date_ext_to_int.
    IF iv_date_format_externe_courant = initial_external_date.
      result = VALUE #( ).
    ELSE.
      cl_abap_datfm=>conv_date_ext_to_int( EXPORTING im_datext = iv_date_format_externe_courant
                                           IMPORTING ex_datint = result ).
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD create.
    result = NEW lcl_app( ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD start_of_selection.
    TYPES tt_description_lines TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF dpr_tv_bapi_description WITH EMPTY KEY.

    DATA project_definition_guid      TYPE bapi_ts_guid-project_definition_guid.
    DATA es_project_definition_detail TYPE bapi_ts_project_def_detail.
    DATA es_extension_out             TYPE bapiparex.
    DATA et_name                      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_ts_name.
    DATA et_description               TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_ts_description.
    DATA et_status                    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_ts_status.
    DATA et_authorization             TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_ts_authorization_out.
    DATA return_tab                   TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapiret2.
    DATA is_extension_in              TYPE bapiparex.
    DATA is_project_definition        TYPE bapi_ts_project_def.
    DATA is_project_definition_upd    TYPE bapi_ts_project_def_upd.

    IF projguid IS NOT INITIAL.
      project_definition_guid = projguid.
    ELSE.
      SELECT SINGLE guid FROM dpr_project WHERE project_id = @projnum INTO @DATA(dpr_project_guid).
      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
        MESSAGE |Project "{ projnum }" not found in table DPR_PROJECT| TYPE 'I' DISPLAY LIKE 'E'.
        RETURN.
      ENDIF.
      project_definition_guid = dpr_project_guid.
    ENDIF.

    CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUS2172_GET_DETAIL'
      EXPORTING
        project_definition_guid      = project_definition_guid
      IMPORTING
        es_project_definition_detail = es_project_definition_detail
        es_extension_out             = es_extension_out
      TABLES
        et_name                      = et_name
        et_description               = et_description
        et_status                    = et_status
        et_authorization             = et_authorization
        return                       = return_tab.

    LOOP AT return_tab REFERENCE INTO DATA(return_line)
         WHERE type CA 'AEX'.
      WRITE / return_line->message.
    ENDLOOP.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      MESSAGE 'Error(s) during GET_DETAIL c.f. messages in the list/spool' TYPE 'I' DISPLAY LIKE 'E'.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    is_extension_in = es_extension_out.
    es_extension_out = VALUE #( ).

    DATA(description_lines) = VALUE tt_description_lines( FOR <description_line> IN et_description
                                                          WHERE ( language = es_project_definition_detail-master_language )
                                                          ( <description_line>-description_line ) ).
    CONCATENATE LINES OF description_lines INTO DATA(project_description) RESPECTING BLANKS.
    cl_dpr_bapi_services=>convert_string_to_rawparts( EXPORTING iv_desc_string = project_description
                                                      IMPORTING ev_desc_part1  = DATA(desc_part1)
                                                                ev_desc_part2  = DATA(desc_part2)
                                                                ev_desc_part3  = DATA(desc_part3)
                                                                ev_desc_part4  = DATA(desc_part4) ).
    " The error "Enter an object number" (DPR_CGPL_MESSAGES003) happens if IS_PROJECT_DEFINITION-PROJECT_ID
    "   is filled, but no error if it's empty!? --> let's keep it empty then...
    is_project_definition = VALUE bapi_ts_project_def(
        project_number               = ''
        project_name_language        = es_project_definition_detail-master_language " es_project_definition_detail-project_name_language
        project_name                 = VALUE #( et_name[ language = es_project_definition_detail-master_language ]-name OPTIONAL ) " es_project_definition_detail-project_name
        project_type                 = es_project_definition_detail-project_type
        project_cause                = es_project_definition_detail-project_cause
        responsible_role_guid        = es_project_definition_detail-responsible_role_guid
        priority                     = es_project_definition_detail-priority
        fixed_start_constraint_type  = es_project_definition_detail-fixed_start_constraint_type
        fixed_start_date             = conv_date_ext_to_int( es_project_definition_detail-fixed_start_date )
        fixed_finish_constraint_type = es_project_definition_detail-fixed_finish_constraint_type
        fixed_finish_date            = conv_date_ext_to_int( es_project_definition_detail-fixed_finish_date )
        calendar                     = es_project_definition_detail-calendar
        sold_to_party_number         = es_project_definition_detail-sold_to_party_number
        customer_number              = es_project_definition_detail-customer_number
        grouping                     = es_project_definition_detail-grouping
        search_field                 = es_project_definition_detail-search_field
        actual_work                  = es_project_definition_detail-actual_work
        actual_work_unit             = es_project_definition_detail-actual_work_unit
        responsible_orga_unit        = es_project_definition_detail-responsible_orga_unit
        project_description_language = es_project_definition_detail-master_language " es_project_definition_detail-project_description_language
        project_description_part1    = desc_part1 " es_project_definition_detail-project_description_part1
        project_description_part2    = desc_part2 " es_project_definition_detail-project_description_part2
        project_description_part3    = desc_part3 " es_project_definition_detail-project_description_part3
        project_description_part4    = desc_part4 " es_project_definition_detail-project_description_part4
        location                     = es_project_definition_detail-location
        allocation_unit              = es_project_definition_detail-allocation_unit
        period_type                  = es_project_definition_detail-period_type
        forecasted_start             = conv_date_ext_to_int( es_project_definition_detail-forecasted_start )
        forecasted_finish            = conv_date_ext_to_int( es_project_definition_detail-forecasted_finish )
        master_language              = es_project_definition_detail-master_language ).
    is_project_definition_upd = VALUE bapi_ts_project_def_upd(
        project_number               = xsdbool( is_project_definition-project_number IS NOT INITIAL )
        project_name_language        = xsdbool( is_project_definition-project_name_language IS NOT INITIAL )
        project_name                 = xsdbool( is_project_definition-project_name IS NOT INITIAL )
        project_type                 = xsdbool( is_project_definition-project_type IS NOT INITIAL )
        project_cause                = xsdbool( is_project_definition-project_cause IS NOT INITIAL )
        responsible_role_guid        = xsdbool( is_project_definition-responsible_role_guid IS NOT INITIAL )
        priority                     = xsdbool( is_project_definition-priority IS NOT INITIAL )
        fixed_start_constraint_type  = xsdbool( is_project_definition-fixed_start_constraint_type IS NOT INITIAL )
        fixed_start_date             = xsdbool( is_project_definition-fixed_start_date IS NOT INITIAL )
        fixed_finish_constraint_type = xsdbool( is_project_definition-fixed_finish_constraint_type IS NOT INITIAL )
        fixed_finish_date            = xsdbool( is_project_definition-fixed_finish_date IS NOT INITIAL )
        calendar                     = xsdbool( is_project_definition-calendar IS NOT INITIAL )
        sold_to_party_number         = xsdbool( is_project_definition-sold_to_party_number IS NOT INITIAL )
        customer_number              = xsdbool( is_project_definition-customer_number IS NOT INITIAL )
        grouping                     = xsdbool( is_project_definition-grouping IS NOT INITIAL )
        search_field                 = xsdbool( is_project_definition-search_field IS NOT INITIAL )
        actual_work                  = xsdbool( is_project_definition-actual_work IS NOT INITIAL )
        actual_work_unit             = xsdbool( is_project_definition-actual_work_unit IS NOT INITIAL )
        responsible_orga_unit        = xsdbool( is_project_definition-responsible_orga_unit IS NOT INITIAL )
        project_description_language = xsdbool( is_project_definition-project_description_language IS NOT INITIAL )
        project_description          = xsdbool(    is_project_definition-project_description_part1 IS NOT INITIAL
                                                OR is_project_definition-project_description_part2 IS NOT INITIAL
                                                OR is_project_definition-project_description_part3 IS NOT INITIAL
                                                OR is_project_definition-project_description_part4 IS NOT INITIAL )
        location                     = xsdbool( is_project_definition-location IS NOT INITIAL )
        allocation_unit              = xsdbool( is_project_definition-allocation_unit IS NOT INITIAL )
        period_type                  = xsdbool( is_project_definition-period_type IS NOT INITIAL )
        forecasted_start             = xsdbool( is_project_definition-forecasted_start IS NOT INITIAL )
        forecasted_finish            = xsdbool( is_project_definition-forecasted_finish IS NOT INITIAL )
        extensions                   = xsdbool( is_extension_in IS NOT INITIAL ) ).

    CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUS2172_CREATE'
      EXPORTING
        is_project_definition     = is_project_definition
        is_project_definition_upd = is_project_definition_upd
        is_extension_in           = is_extension_in
      IMPORTING
        es_extension_out          = es_extension_out
      TABLES
        return                    = return_tab.

    LOOP AT return_tab REFERENCE INTO return_line
         WHERE type CA 'AEX'.
      WRITE : / return_line->type, return_line->number, return_line->id, return_line->message.
    ENDLOOP.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_CPROJECTS_ROLLBACK_WORK'
        TABLES
          return = return_tab.
      MESSAGE 'Error(s) during CREATE c.f. messages in the list/spool' TYPE 'I' DISPLAY LIKE 'E'.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    LOOP AT return_tab REFERENCE INTO return_line.
      WRITE : / return_line->type, return_line->number, return_line->id, return_line->message.
    ENDLOOP.

    IF 0 = 1.
      MESSAGE s114(dpr_bapi) ##MG_MISSING.
    ENDIF.
    DATA(success_message) = VALUE #( return_tab[ id     = 'DPR_BAPI'
                                                 number = '114' ] OPTIONAL ).

    CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_CPROJECTS_COMMIT_WORK'
      TABLES
        return = return_tab.

    LOOP AT return_tab REFERENCE INTO return_line.
      WRITE : / return_line->type, return_line->number, return_line->id, return_line->message.
    ENDLOOP.

    IF success_message IS NOT INITIAL.
      DATA(project_guid) = CONV dpr_project-guid( success_message-message_v1 ).
      SELECT SINGLE project_id FROM dpr_project WHERE guid = @project_guid INTO @DATA(project_id).
      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        WRITE / |GUID { project_guid } = Project { project_id } |.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Detecting CDS View 2nd Level Dependencies on Custom Fields in SAP Transport Cross Reference Check
entry.content:
Introduction

When transporting custom CDS views, dependency management becomes critical, especially if CDS views rely on custom fields added via appends to SAP standard tables. SAP Note [2964512] documents a limitation: the standard cross reference check (as run in transaction `/SDF/TRCHECK` or Change Request Management) does not detect â€œ2nd levelâ€ dependenciesâ€”cases where your CDS view depends on fields from a *custom append* to a standard table. This can cause runtime errors after transport if the append is missing in the target system.

This blog describes how I worked around this by customizing the check logic so it explicitly includes Z-fields in CDS dependencies, letting you catch these hidden dependencies before you move your transports.

The Problem

Imagine youâ€™re transporting a custom CDS view that selects fields from a SAP standard table. The table itself has been extended by a custom append containing several Z* fields. If the CDS view uses one of these Z-fields and the append is not present in the target system, the import will fail with a runtime dump. Unfortunately, the standard cross reference check does not flag these second-level dependencies, so you donâ€™t know about the missing append until itâ€™s too late.

Custom Solution Overview

To address this limitation, I followed these steps:

1. Copied the Standard Report and Includes
I made a custom copy of `/SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK` and all its includes:

| Standard | Custom |
|------------------|----------------------|
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK | ZCMO_TR_CHECK |
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_FORMS | ZCMO_TR_CHECK_FORMS |
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_INC1 | ZCMO_TR_CHECK_INC1 |
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_INC2 | ZCMO_TR_CHECK_INC2 |
| /SDF/_TR_CHECK_GET_SID_RFCF01 | ZTR_CHECK_GET_SID_RFCF01 |

 

2. Used a Custom Copy of the Dependency Analyzer FM
In the custom include (formerly `/SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_FORMS` at line 1128), I replaced the standard call:

CALL FUNCTION '/SDF/TEAP_ENVI_ANA'.
with
CALL FUNCTION 'ZTEAP_ENVI_ANA'.

3. Enhanced the FM to Detect Z-fields in Appends
Inside the custom FM (`ZTEAP_ENVI_ANA`), after the section:
* Delete MSAG
DELETE lt_objs_ref_tab WHERE ref_obj_type = 'MSAG'.

I added logic to explicitly look for Z-fields in the tables referenced by the CDS view. This augments the standard cross-reference logic to handle this otherwise missed scenario.


    TYPES : BEGIN OF ty_ref_obj,
              obj_name TYPE ddstrucobjname,
            END OF ty_ref_obj.


    TYPES : BEGIN OF ty_tadir,
              rollname TYPE sobj_name,
            END OF ty_tadir.

    DATA : lt_ref_obj TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_ref_obj.
    DATA : lt_tadir_tmp TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_tadir.

    DATA(lt_tmp) = lt_objs_ref_tab.

    SORT lt_tmp BY obj_name.
    DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_tmp COMPARING obj_name.
    DELETE lt_tmp WHERE ref_obj_type <> 'TABL'.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING lt_tmp TO lt_ref_obj.

    DATA lt_dd03l TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF dd03l.
    DATA lt_tadir_new TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tadir.
    DATA lt_dd03nd TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF dd03nd.

    SELECT *
      FROM dd03nd
      INTO TABLE lt_dd03nd
      FOR ALL ENTRIES IN lt_ref_obj
      WHERE strucobjn = lt_ref_obj-obj_name
      AND rollname  LIKE 'Z%'.

    SORT lt_dd03nd BY strucobjn rollname.
    DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_dd03nd COMPARING strucobjn rollname.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING lt_dd03nd TO lt_tadir_tmp.

    SELECT *
      FROM tadir
      INTO TABLE lt_tadir_new
      FOR ALL ENTRIES IN lt_tadir_tmp
      WHERE obj_name = lt_tadir_tmp-rollname.

    DATA(lt_objs_ref_tab_new) = lt_tmp.
    CLEAR lt_objs_ref_tab_new.
    SORT lt_tmp BY obj_name ref_obj_name.
    LOOP AT lt_tmp INTO DATA(wa_ref).
      LOOP AT lt_dd03nd INTO DATA(wa_dd03nd) WHERE strucobjn = wa_ref-obj_name.
        wa_ref-ref_obj_name = wa_dd03nd-rollname.
        LOOP AT lt_tadir_new INTO DATA(wa_tadir) WHERE obj_name = wa_dd03nd-rollname.
          wa_ref-ref_pgmid = wa_tadir-pgmid.
          wa_ref-ref_obj_type = wa_tadir-object.
          APPEND wa_ref TO lt_objs_ref_tab_new.
          CLEAR wa_tadir.
        ENDLOOP.
        CLEAR wa_dd03nd.
      ENDLOOP.
      CLEAR wa_ref.
    ENDLOOP.


    APPEND LINES OF lt_objs_ref_tab_new TO lt_objs_ref_tab.

 

Outcome & Benefits

With this logic in place, running your custom version of the cross reference check will now also surface missing custom Z-fields referenced by CDS views. This eliminates false negatives and gives you a complete picture of technical dependencies, meaning you can catch potential short dumps or import errors *before* they occur in production.

Conclusion

If youâ€™re dealing with custom extensions to SAP standard tables and building CDS views on top of those, incorporating this enhancement into your transport process can help you proactively spot and resolve these tricky second-level dependencies. This saves both time and effortâ€”and avoids unexpected surprises during system imports.

Have you implemented other tricks or enhancements around dependency checks and transports? Let me know in the comments!

entry.title: 2025 set the pace, 2026 wins the race: ABAP AI with Joule, VS Code, and CCM
entry.content:
Back from a blissful Christmas/New Year reset and sprinting to the keyboardâ€”time to swap hot cocoa for hot commits. 2025 made the promise real: prompts â†’ projects, minutes not weeks, and Joule as ABAPâ€™s turbo button. Now we scale in 2026: agentic flows over widgets, VS Code firstâ€‘class, and AIâ€‘driven Custom Code Migration as the headline act. Goodbye 2025, and happy New Year 2026â€”letâ€™s ship.

What happened in 2025 and what are the peaks of 2026? Stay with me for a full retrospective of ABAP AI in 2025 and sneak preview into 2026:

Build fast (Joule on the keyboard)

  • Real-time help that knows ABAP Cloud: context-aware suggestions, code prediction, and clean-core patterns.
  • Explain anything: ABAP and CDS code explained in plain languageâ€”no more reverse-engineering marathons.
  • Tests on tap: Instant unit tests for ABAP and CDS.
  • Roll your own AI: ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM to plug governed GenAI into ABAP scenarios.

Ship whole apps (from help to â€œdoneâ€)

  • OData UI Service from Scratch Wizard + Joule chat: full RAP apps in minutesâ€”entities, behavior, service binding, OData.
  • RAP Business Logic Prediction: validations and determinations generated in-context, following RAP best practices.
  • OData consumption in seconds: /consume generates tailored client proxy code and examples.
  • Extensibility AI Assistant (Public Cloud): add custom fields, find business contexts, enable usage, locate value helps, discover BADIsâ€”by asking.

Migrate with confidence (legacy to S/4HANA-ready)

  • /docs for migration: chat with SAP Help, simplification items, and cookbooksâ€”answers tied to your scenario.
  • Explain legacy code: purpose, flow, data dependenciesâ€”thousands-line â€œmysteryâ€ programs, understood in seconds.
  • Explain ATC findings: root cause, business impact, recommended APIs, and fix examples for S/4 readiness checks.
  • Custom Code Migration AI Assistant (Private 2025): bring all of the above into your S4/HANA simplification with 2025 PCE delivery
  • Next up: the standalone Custom Code Migration Application on BTP ABAP connects to any ERP (on-prem or cloud) for RISE and deliver code adaptation proposals with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS01.

Availability and how to start

  • Joule for Developers is free for another year: 8019124 (customers), 8019541 (TDD partners). Available for BTP ABAP, S/4HANA Cloud Public, and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (2025). Read more on The AI Revolution Accelerates â€“ Chapter 2 Awaits.
