  • Use the ABAP AI SDK to build, manage and operate your own AI scenarios in your ABAP developments.
  • Adopt the Custom Code Migration AI Assistant (Private 2025) and the BTP-based Custom Code Migration Application for cross-system analysis soon to come
  • Explore SAP Help and Bolg community content from Sonja Lienard and Alexander Rother.

A sneak-peek of 2026

2025 proved ABAP AI. 2026 scales itâ€”fast. The shift: from features to frameworks, from capabilities to flows, from PoCs to enterprise-grade AI across the ABAP stack.

Agentic ABAP AI: workflows, not widgets

  • Agent-led flows own the whole task: understand â†’ transform â†’ test â†’ enforce clean core.
  • ABAP Agentic AI Flow and side-by-side agents become standard; existing use cases migrate into agents available also for older SAP Cloud ERP Private versions.
  • Aligned with Jouleâ€™s agentic direction and interoperable with industry patterns.

Joule everywhere: VS Code goes first class

  • VS Code support: ABAP language server, ABAP MCP server, native Joule for Developers.
  • One feel across Eclipse, VS Code, and future cloud IDEsâ€”AI where devs actually work.
  • Next J4D wave: sharper suggestions, clearer explanations, feedback loops

Flagship 2026: AI-driven Custom Code Migration (CCM)

  • Double down on custom code adaptation proposal, follow up by clean-core recommendations, fit-to-standard analysis, clean core propose transformations, and code explain extension to more ABAP legacy objects
  • Deep agentic integration and customer-ready RISE scenariosâ€”CCM is the hero use case.

Foundations level up: SDK, ABAP LLMs, benchmarking

  • AI SDK adds orchestration, structured outputs, streaming, and broader compatibility.
  • SAP-trained ABAP LLMs become consumable for higher-fidelity code understanding and generation.
  • Benchmarking and telemetry are standardized and automated for accuracy, price, and performance.

ABAP-tuned LLMs: SAP doubles down via AI Core

  • Continue doubling down on ABAP AI models that bake in ABAP/CDS knowledge, SAP semantics, and cleanâ€‘core patterns for higherâ€‘fidelity understanding and safer code generation.
  • Delivered through AI Core: enterprise governed access to manage the execution and operations of AI assets in a standardized, scalable, and hyperscaler-agnostic manner. 
  • Plug-and-play integration: native hooks in Joule for Developers and the ABAP AI SDK, plus standardized benchmarking and telemetry as usage scales.

Bottom line for 2026

Thatâ€™s the play: ship early, scale smart, keep the core cleanâ€”agentic flows doing the heavy lifting, Joule firstâ€‘class in VS Code, and AIâ€‘driven CCM leading the migration sprint while ABAPâ€‘tuned models via AI Core keep it governed. From prompts to productionâ€”minutes, not weeks.  

Happy New Year 2026â€” If 2025 unlocked ABAP AIâ€™s potential, 2026 will make ABAP AI the core of ABAP development.

entry.title: A Handy Custom Report to Scan SAP CDS Views for Usage of Search Strings
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever wished for an easier way to scan all your SAP CDS Views for particular strings, just as easily as you can do with ABAP reports via program RS_ABAP_SOURCE_SCAN? If you work with CDS extensivelyâ€”especially with custom developmentsâ€”the need often arises to mass-search your repository for usage of table names, fields, function modules, or any arbitrary string within CDS source code.

Inspired by this requirement, I built a custom utility report (ZSCAN_CDS_VIEWS) that you can run directly from SE38. It allows you to enter a list of search strings and instantly scans all CDS Views whose names begin with "Z," showing exactly which CDS View and which code line contains your search string. This can be particularly helpful during refactoring, code reviews, or cleanup tasks.

You can also modify the selection criteria and adjust other logic as needed to suit your specific requirements.

You might already be aware that ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in Eclipse offer an "ABAP Source Search" feature, which is also capable of searching through CDS View sources. This tool can be handy for performing code searches directly within your development environment.

However, in my experience, the source search in ADT is not as user-friendly for some scenarios:

  • The UI can be a bit overwhelming, especially if you just want a quick list of where a string is used across dozens or hundreds of custom CDS Views.
  • It's not easy to search for multiple strings at once.

Prerequisites

To make this report work, youâ€™ll need the Function Module /ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA available and active in your SAP system. This FM is used to read HANA DDL sources for CDS views. Internally, it calls the method /abex/cl_main_hana~read_src to fetch the source code lines.

How the Solution Works

The approach is simple but very effective:

  1. Fetch All Custom CDS Views: The program selects all entries in table DDDDLSRC where DDLNAME starts with 'Z'.
  2. Read Source for Each View: For each CDS View found, it uses /ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA to fetch the source code as a table of strings.
  3. Scan for Your Search Strings: For every entry in your search list, it scans the code using the ABAP FIND ALL OCCURRENCES OF ... IN TABLE statement, efficiently identifying every match.
  4. Show the Results in ALV: The results are shown in a flexible ALV grid, making it easy to filter, sort, or export as needed.

ABAP Code

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZSCAN_CDS_VIEWS
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT zscan_cds_views.

DATA: gv_sstring TYPE text255.
SELECT-OPTIONS sstring FOR gv_sstring NO INTERVALS.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_final,
         objectname   TYPE objectname,
         searchstring TYPE text255,
         line         TYPE text255,
       END OF ty_final.

DATA: gt_final    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_final,
      gt_src      TYPE /abex/string_tt,
      gt_ddddlsrc TYPE TABLE OF ddddlsrc,
      gv_name     TYPE objectname.

FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_ddddlsrc> TYPE ddddlsrc,
               <fs_src>      TYPE LINE OF /abex/string_tt,
               <fs_result>   TYPE match_result.

" --- Read all CDS sources into internal table, where DDL name starts with Z
SELECT * FROM ddddlsrc
  INTO TABLE @gt_ddddlsrc
  WHERE ddlname LIKE 'Z%'.

LOOP AT gt_ddddlsrc ASSIGNING <fs_ddddlsrc>.

  gv_name = to_upper( <fs_ddddlsrc>-ddlname ).

  " --- Call function to get the CDS source code
  CALL FUNCTION '/ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA'
    EXPORTING
      lv_ddlname        = gv_name
      iv_get_auth_check = abap_false
    IMPORTING
      et_src=gt_src
    EXCEPTIONS
      no_authority      = 1
      OTHERS            = 2.

  " --- Convert gt_src to a flat table for FIND
  DATA(gt_source) = VALUE abaptxt255_tab( FOR src IN gt_src ( line = src ) ).

  LOOP AT sstring INTO DATA(ls_sstring) ##into_ok.
    FIND ALL OCCURRENCES OF ls_sstring-low IN TABLE gt_source
      IN CHARACTER MODE
      IGNORING CASE
      RESULTS DATA(lt_results).

    IF lt_results IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT lt_results ASSIGNING <fs_result>.
        TRY.
            APPEND VALUE ty_final(
              objectname   = gv_name
              searchstring = ls_sstring-low
              line         = gt_src[ <fs_result>-line ]
            ) TO gt_final.
          CATCH cx_sy_itab_line_not_found.
        ENDTRY.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.

ENDLOOP.

" --- Display with SALV
DATA: lo_alv TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table.
cl_salv_table=>factory(
  IMPORTING
    r_salv_table = lo_alv
  CHANGING
    t_table      = gt_final ).

DATA(lo_columns) = lo_alv->get_columns( ).
lo_columns->get_column( 'SEARCHSTRING' )->set_long_text( 'Search String' ).
lo_columns->get_column( 'LINE' )->set_long_text( 'Code Line' ).
lo_columns->set_optimize( abap_true ).
lo_alv->display( ).

A Few Implementation Notes

  • Performance: For large systems with lots of CDS Views, this report might take a little time to run. You can adjust the initial selection in the SELECT statement (e.g., limit to a specific namespace) if needed.
  • Enhancements: You could easily enhance this to include other filters, save the results, or adjust the output fields. The core scan logic is highly flexible.
  • Authorization: Keep in mind that fucntion module /ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA must be available and properly authorized for your user.

Conclusion

This utility has saved me a lot of manual searching and helped me understand the impact of changes and references within CDS Views much quicker. I hope you find it just as useful. If you try this out and find it helpful, or if you enhance it or spot improvement opportunities, please do share your experiences in the comments.

Happy coding.

Execution 

I want to check how many CDS views use TVARVC variables. I provided the variable names in the search string as input and executed the report.

Output

entry.title: How To Consume External APIs in S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (PCE) 2023 via RAP Framework
entry.content:
Scenario:
Suppose we need to expose images related to a "PickTicket" from an external system, making them available in SAP via a custom OData service.

Steps Overview

1. Create a Custom Entity CDS View
2. Create Service Definition
3. Create Service Binding
4. Implement ABAP Class to Consume the External API
5. Test the OData Service

1. Create a Custom Entity (CDS View)

Start by defining a **custom entity** to represent the data structure for the API response:

@EndUserText.label: 'Custom Entity for Image Data'
@ObjectModel: {
query: {
implementedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_IMAGESET'
}
}
define root custom entity ZCE_IMAGESET
{
key pickticketid : abap.char(20);
key urlshortlivedthumbnail : abap.char(255);
trigger_ : abap.char(20);
source : abap.char(40);
imageid : abap.char(20);
urlthumbnail : abap.char(255);
urlshortlived : abap.char(255);
}

This entity acts as a **virtual view**â€”data retrieval is handled by an ABAP class (see `implementedBy` above).

2. Create a Service Definition

Expose the custom entity in your service definition:

@EndUserText.label: 'zsd_imageset'
define service Zsd_imageset {
expose ZCE_IMAGESET;
}

3. Create a Service Binding

Next, create a **service binding**â€”for example, `ZSB_IMAGESET` for OData V4â€”which generates the OData endpoint for your application. *Use the standard RAP tools in Eclipse or ADT to create this binding from the CDS service definition.*

4. Implement the ABAP Class to Handle API Call

Define the ABAP class (`zcl_imageset`) to fetch and provide data from the external API.
Use the **RAP Query Provider Interface** (`if_rap_query_provider`) for custom data provisioning:

Class Definition

CLASS zcl_imageset DEFINITION
PUBLIC
FINAL
CREATE PUBLIC .

PUBLIC SECTION.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_imageset,
trigger TYPE char20,
pickticketid TYPE char20,
source TYPE char40,
imageid TYPE char20,
urlthumbnail TYPE char255,
urlshortlived TYPE char255,
urlshortlivedthumbnail TYPE char255,
END OF ty_imageset.

TYPES: tt_imageset TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_imageset WITH EMPTY KEY.

INTERFACES if_rap_query_provider.
PROTECTED SECTION.
PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.

Class Implementation

CLASS ZCL_IMAGESET IMPLEMENTATION.

METHOD if_rap_query_provider~select.

DATA lt_images TYPE tt_imageset.
DATA lv_pickticketid TYPE string.

" Get filter (PickTicketId)

DATA(lo_filter) = io_request->get_filter( )->get_as_sql_string( ).
DATA(lv_offset) = io_request->get_paging( )->get_offset( ).
DATA(lv_page_size) = io_request->get_paging( )->get_page_size( ).
DATA(lv_max_rows) = COND #( WHEN lv_page_size = if_rap_query_paging=>page_size_unlimited THEN 0
ELSE lv_page_size ).
DATA(lt_sort_table) = VALUE string_table( FOR ls_sort_element IN io_request->get_sort_elements( )
( ls_sort_element-element_name && COND #( WHEN ls_sort_element-descending = abap_true THEN ` descending` ELSE ` ascending` ) ) ).
CONCATENATE 'PICKTICKETID ' 'SOURCE'
INTO DATA(lv_default_sort) SEPARATED BY ',' .
DATA(lv_sort_string) = COND #( WHEN lt_sort_table IS INITIAL THEN lv_default_sort
ELSE concat_lines_of( table = lt_sort_table sep = ',' ) ).


IF io_request IS BOUND.
DATA(lt_expressions) = io_request->get_filter( )->get_as_ranges( ).


LOOP AT lt_expressions INTO DATA(ls_expr).
IF ls_expr-name = 'PICKTICKETID'.
LOOP AT ls_expr-range INTO DATA(ls_range).
IF ls_range-option = 'EQ'.
lv_pickticketid = ls_range-low.
EXIT.
ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.
EXIT.
ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

ENDIF.

" Build target URL for the external request
DATA(lv_url) = |https://<external domain url>/pickTickets/{ lv_pickticketid }/images|.

" Create HTTP client and set headers
DATA lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.
cl_http_client=>create_by_url(
EXPORTING url = lv_url
IMPORTING client = lo_http_client
).
lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'client_id' value = '<your_client_id>' ).
lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'client_secret' value = '<your_client_secret>' ).
lo_http_client->send( ).
lo_http_client->receive( ).
DATA(lv_response) = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
lo_http_client->close( ).

" Parse JSON response to ABAP table
DATA(lo_json) = NEW /ui2/cl_json( ).
lo_json->deserialize(
EXPORTING json = lv_response
CHANGING data = lt_images
).

" Return the data
io_response->set_total_number_of_records( lines( lt_images ) ).
io_response->set_data( lt_images ).

ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

*Replace* `<external domain url>`, `<your_client_id>`, and `<your_client_secret>` *with real values.*

5. Publish and Test Your OData Service

  • Use `/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE` or the service binding UI in Eclipse/ADT to publish your OData service.
  • Test the endpoint with a filter on `PickTicketId`:
    Example: /sap/opu/odata/sap/ZSB_IMAGESET/ZCE_IMAGESET?$filter= pickticketid eq '123456'

Key Takeaways

  • Custom Entities in RAP allow you to virtualize data from external sources as standard OData.
  • You can leverage the **HTTP client functionalities** in ABAP to fetch data from any REST API.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud stack are open for API-driven architectures.
  • Make sure to treat secrets and API credentials securelyâ€”avoid hardcoding in productive code.

Conclusion

You now have a **custom OData service** in SAP S/4HANA PCE, powered by the RAP framework, which brings in dynamic data from an **external API**. You can enhance, secure, and extend this pattern for many integration use casesâ€”be it analytics dashboards, mobile apps, or UI5/Fiori apps!

Let me know your feedback, or reach out for specific questions.

entry.title: Fixing Warranty Inheritance Issues in SAP PM: A Custom ABAP Report
entry.content:
In SAP Plant Maintenance (PM), warranty periods for technical objects are designed to be inherited automatically from superior functional locations to their subordinate locations. This is part of the standard functionality. However, in practice, this inheritance sometimes fails... leading to inconsistencies and manual corrections that consume time and create frustration for PM administrators.

The Problem

Although SAP provides automatic inheritance for warranty start and end dates, there are cases where this process does not work as expected. Common reasons include:

  • Data inconsistencies in the hierarchy.
  • Missing or incorrect object numbers.
  • Technical issues during creation or update of functional locations.

When inheritance fails, subordinate locations remain without warranty data, which can impact maintenance planning and compliance.

The Solution

Instead of relying solely on the standard process, we developed a lightweight ABAP report that ensures warranty data consistency across the hierarchy. The report reads warranty start and end dates from the parent functional location and applies them to all subordinate locations, writing the data directly into the BGMKOBJ table.

Key Features

  • Input: Superior functional location.
  • Logic: Reads warranty data from the parent and applies it to all child locations.
  • Execution: Uses MODIFY on BGMKOBJ, which automatically decides whether to update existing records or insert new ones.
  • Modes: Test mode for simulation and productive mode for actual updates.

Core Logic

LOOP AT lt_child ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<child>).
  IF p_test = abap_true.
    lv_status = |SIMULATION: Location { <child>-tplnr } would be updated or newly created.|.
  ELSE.
    CLEAR wa_bgmkobj_child.
    wa_bgmkobj_child = wa_bgmkobj_parent.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-j_objnr = <child>-objnr.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erdat   = sy-datum.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erzei   = sy-uzeit.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-gaerb   = 'X'.

    " MODIFY automatically decides whether to INSERT or UPDATE
    MODIFY bgmkobj FROM _bgmkobj_child.

    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      lv_status = |Location { <child>-tplnr } successfully processed.|.
    ELSE.
      lv_status = |Error processing location { <child>-tplnr }.|.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

  WRITE: / lv_status.
ENDLOOP.

entry.title: Quick Start with SAP HANA PAL: Basic Example Implementation
entry.content:
What is PAL in SAP?

In SAP, PAL stands for Predictive Analysis Library.
Itâ€™s a collection of built-in, pre-delivered machine learning and statistical algorithms that run directly inside SAP HANA (in-memory database). Instead of exporting data to an external ML tool (like Python, R, etc.), PAL allows you to do predictive analytics inside HANA itself, close to the data.

Key Capabilities 

  • In-Database Predictive Processing: PAL enables running ML/statistical algorithms within the HANA database itself, eliminating the need to export data to external tools. This delivers high performance and reduces data latency.

  • Rich Algorithm Portfolio: PAL provides a wide spectrum of built-in algorithms: classification (decision trees, logistic regression, NaÃ¯ve Bayes), regression (linear, polynomial), clustering (k-means, DBSCAN), time-series forecasting (ARIMA, exponential smoothing), association rules, anomaly detection, and more.

  • SQL/Script-Based Invocation: All PAL algorithms are exposed as SQL Script procedures. Developers can embed calls directly in SQL or stored procedures, enabling seamless integration with existing database logic without switching environments.

     

    SAP HANAâ€™s SQL Script is an extension of SQL. It includes enhanced control-flow capabilities and lets developers define complex application logic inside database procedures. However, it is difficult to describe predictive analysis logic with procedures.

    Why PAL was introduced
    For example, an application may need to perform a cluster analysis in a huge customer table with 1T records. It is impossible to implement the analysis in a procedure using the simple classic K-means algorithms, or with more complicated algorithms in the data-mining area. Transferring large tables to the application server to perform the K-means calculation is also costly.

    Prerequisites

  • ADT (ABAP Development Toolkit) 
  • ABAP GUI Logon with system access

    Segmentation Analysis

  • Open ABAP Perspective:
    Window â†’ Perspective â†’ Open Perspective â†’ ABAP

  • Create an ABAP Project:
    Use the left panel â†’ Create ABAP Project â†’ connect to your SAP system

  • Define AMDP Procedures:
    Create AMDP procedures to define input/output structures for the PAL algorithm

  • Create an ABAP Report:

    1. Fetch the required data
    2. Set algorithm parameters
    3. Call the AMDP procedure to run the PAL algorithm
    4. Display or store the results

    Predefined PAL Algorithms Available in SAP HANA
    The Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) defines functions that can be called from within SQL Script procedures to perform analytic algorithms. This release of PAL includes classic and universal predictive analysis algorithms in ten data-mining categories:

    • Clustering

    • Classification

    • Regression

    • Association

    • Time Series

    • Preprocessing

    • Statistics

    • Social Network Analysis

    • Recommender System

    • Miscellaneous

        Checking PAL Installation 
             To confirm that the PAL procedures were installed successfully, you can check the following three public views:

  • sys.afl.areas

  • sys.afl_packages

  • sys.afl_functions

   These views are granted to the PUBLIC role and can be accessed by anyone.
   To check the views, run the following SQL statements:

 
SELECT * FROM "SYS"."AFL_AREAS" WHERE AREA_NAME = 'AFLPAL';
SELECT * FROM "SYS"."AFL_PACKAGES" WHERE AREA_NAME = 'AFLPAL';
SELECT * FROM "SYS"."AFL_FUNCTIONS" WHERE AREA_NAME = 'AFLPAL';


Example for Classification Algorithm

       AMDP class: It acts as a bridge between ABAP and SAP HANA PAL. It allows us to define the input and output structures and call the PAL algorithms directly from ABAP, enabling in-database predictive analytics without moving data outside HANA.

CLASS cl_demo DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES : if_amdp_marker_hdb.

    TYPES : BEGIN OF ty_input,
              From_node TYPE c LENGTH 30,
              To_node   TYPE c LENGTH 30,
            END OF ty_input,

            tt_input TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_input WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_param,
              name       TYPE c LENGTH 60,
              intargs    TYPE i,
              doubleargs TYPE f,
              stringargs TYPE c LENGTH 100,
            END OF ty_param,

            tt_param TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_param WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_result,
              node TYPE c LENGTH 30,
              rank TYPE f,
            END OF ty_result,

            tt_result TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_result WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_user_count,
              role_name  TYPE string,
              user_count TYPE i,
            END OF ty_user_count,

            tt_user_count TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_user_count WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_scaling_input,
              data_id    TYPE i,
              count TYPE i,
              rank TYPE f,
            END OF ty_scaling_input,

            tt_scaling_input TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_scaling_input WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_scaling_param,
              name       TYPE c LENGTH 30,
              intargs    TYPE i,
              doubleargs TYPE f,
              stringargs TYPE c LENGTH 30,
            END OF ty_scaling_param,

            tt_scaling_param TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_scaling_param WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_res,
              data_id    TYPE i,
              count TYPE i,
              rank TYPE f,
            END OF ty_res,

            tt_res TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_res WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_model,
              id            TYPE i,
              model_content TYPE c LENGTH 5000,
            END OF ty_model,

            tt_model TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_model WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_statistics,
              stat_name  TYPE c LENGTH 256,
              stat_value TYPE c LENGTH 1000,
            END OF ty_statistics,

            tt_statistics TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_statistics WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_placeholder,
              param_name   TYPE c LENGTH 256,
              int_value    TYPE i,
              double_value TYPE f,
              string_value TYPE c LENGTH 1000,
            END OF ty_placeholder,

            tt_placeholder TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_placeholder WITH EMPTY KEY.



    METHODS : run_pagerank
      IMPORTING
        VALUE(it_data)   TYPE tt_input
        VALUE(it_param)  TYPE tt_param OPTIONAL
      EXPORTING
        VALUE(it_result) TYPE tt_result,

      run_scaling
        IMPORTING
                  VALUE(it_input)       TYPE tt_scaling_input
                  VALUE(it_param)       TYPE tt_scaling_param OPTIONAL
        EXPORTING
                  VALUE(it_res)         TYPE tt_res
                  VALUE(it_model)       TYPE tt_model
                  VALUE(it_statistics)  TYPE tt_statistics
                  VALUE(it_placeholder) TYPE tt_placeholder
        RAISING   cx_amdp_error.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS cl_demo IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD run_pagerank BY DATABASE
   PROCEDURE FOR HDB
   LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY.

    CALL _SYS_AFL.PAL_PAGERANK(:it_data, :it_param, :it_result);

  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD run_scaling BY DATABASE
     PROCEDURE FOR HDB
     LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY.

    CALL _SYS_AFL.PAL_SCALE(:it_input, :it_param, :it_res, :it_model, :it_statistics, :it_placeholder );

  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

To execute PAL algorithms in SAP HANA, we create an ABAP report program. This program calls the methods defined in the AMDP class, fetches the required data, sets the necessary algorithm parameters, runs the predictive procedures, and captures the results for analysis or further processing. 

REPORT zpal_demo.

DATA: lt_input               TYPE cl_demo=>tt_input,
      ls_input               LIKE LINE OF lt_input,
      lr_table               TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table,
      lt_param               TYPE cl_demo=>tt_param,
      ls_param               LIKE LINE OF lt_param,
      lt_result              TYPE cl_demo=>tt_result,           
      lt_scale_input         TYPE cl_demo=>tt_scaling_input,
      lt_scale_param         TYPE cl_demo=>tt_scaling_param,
      lt_scale_result        TYPE cl_demo=>tt_res,
      lt_scale_stcs          TYPE cl_demo=>tt_statistics,
      lt_scale_model         TYPE cl_demo=>tt_model,
      lt_scale_placeholder   TYPE cl_demo=>tt_placeholder,
      lr_pagerank            TYPE REF TO cl_demo,
      lr_scaling             TYPE REF TO cl_demo.

   START-OF-SELECTION.

  SELECT FROM (Data source)
        FIELDS * INTO TABLE (lt_final).

  "Run pagerank clustering
  CREATE OBJECT lr_pagerank.
  TRY.
      CALL METHOD lr_pagerank->run_pagerank
        EXPORTING
          it_data   = CONV #( lt_final )
          it_param  = lt_param
        IMPORTING
          it_result = lt_result.
    CATCH cx_amdp_version_mismatch INTO DATA(ls_error).
      CALL METHOD ls_error->get_text
        RECEIVING
          result = DATA(ls_txt).

  ENDTRY.

    "Parameters
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'SCALING_METHOD' intargs = 0 doubleargs = 0 stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'Z-SCORE_METHOD' intargs = 0 doubleargs = 0 stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'NEW_MAX'        intargs = 0 doubleargs = '1.0' stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'NEW_MIN'        intargs = 0 doubleargs = '0.0' stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'DIVISION_BY_ZERO_HANDLER' intargs = 0 doubleargs = 0 stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.

  CREATE OBJECT lr_scaling.
  TRY.
      CALL METHOD lr_scaling->run_scaling
        EXPORTING
          it_input       = lt_scaling_input
          it_param       = lt_scale_param
        IMPORTING
          it_res         = lt_scale_result
          it_model       = lt_scale_model
          it_statistics  = lt_scale_stcs
          it_placeholder = lt_scale_placeholder.

    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(ls_scale_error).
      CALL METHOD ls_scale_error->get_text
        RECEIVING
          result = DATA(ls_scale_txt).
      CALL METHOD ls_scale_error->get_longtext
        RECEIVING
          result = DATA(ls_long_txt).

  ENDTRY.

 Note:  While creating the parameter table, make sure to refer carefully to the official PAL documentation for the specific algorithm you are using. The structure and fields of the parameter table may differ based on the algorithm requirements, so modify it accordingly before execution.

The official PAL documentation will be attached at the end of this article for reference.

Example for including ISLM into Embeddings

*ISLM Connectivity
   DATA(lo_vector_api) =  cl_aic_islm_embed_api_factory=>get( )->create_instance( 'EMBEDDING' ).

  To create the Intelligent Scenario please refer this blog:
 Unlocking the Power of Generative AI with Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM)

Common error we face while working with PAL procedures:
Could not execute 'CALL SYS.AFLLANG_WRAPPER_PROCEDURE_CREATE ('area_name', 'function_name', 'schema_name', ...' SAP DBTech JDBC: [259]: invalid table name: Could not find table/view SIGNATURE_TABLE in schema PA0001: line 2 col 34 (at pos 107).

How to Resolve this problem?.

The above-mentioned error usually occurs when the mandatory fields in the parameter table are missing or incorrectly defined.

Each PAL algorithm has its own official SAP documentation that specifies the required parameter fields and their data types. Itâ€™s important to refer to the respective document while creating the parameter table to avoid such errors.

SAP PAL Documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM/319d36de4fd64ac3afbf91b1fb3ce8de/pal-procedures-f652a81.html?locale=en-US 

Conclusion
SAP HANA PAL enables performing machine learning directly inside the HANA database, ensuring faster processing and real-time insights. With algorithms like clustering, classification, and regression, it helps build intelligent, data-driven applications seamlessly integrated within the SAP environment.

What's Next?


Here are some other important blogs to learn HANA PAL:
Exploring ML Explainability in SAP HANA PAL - AutoML

Text Embedding Service in SAP HANA Cloud Predictive Analysis Library (PAL)

entry.title: Proactive Warranty Monitoring in SAP PM: A Custom ABAP Solution
entry.content:
The Challenge

The requirement was clear:
"How can we be reminded of expiring warranties directly from SAP ERP?"
Unfortunately, SAP standard does not provide such functionality. Without proactive alerts, maintenance teams risk missing deadlines for warranty claims, leading to unnecessary costs.

The Solution

I developed Report Y_PM_GEWAEHRL_ENDE_LISTE, a simple yet powerful ABAP program that:

  • Scans functional locations and equipment for warranty periods.
  • Calculates remaining days until warranty end.
  • Highlights objects within the configured lead time (default: 90 days).
  • Optionally sends an email notification listing all affected objects.

This approach ensures maintenance teams have enough time to plan corrective actions or initiate warranty claims.

Key Features

  • Configurable lead time: Default is 90 days, but can be adjusted.
  • Dual scope: Works for both technical places and equipment.
  • Color-coded output: Green for active warranties, red for expired or near expiration.
  • Email integration: Sends a summary to a specified recipient when conditions are met.

Core Logic

The report:

  1. Reads warranty start and end dates from BGMKOBJ.
  2. Compares current date with warranty end date.
  3. Collects all objects where remaining days â‰¤ lead time.
  4. Displays results in a formatted list and optionally sends an email.

Email Example:
Subject: SAP System Notification: Warranties Expiring Soon
Body:

Functional Location TPL-1001 | Start: 01.01.2024 | End: 31.12.2025 | Remaining: 45 days
Equipment EQ-2005 | Start: 15.02.2024 | End: 15.02.2025 | Remaining: 30 days

 

Benefits

  • Proactive maintenance planning.
  • Reduced risk of missed warranty claims.
  • Automated notifications for better compliance.
  • Simple integration into existing SAP PM processes.
" --- Check warranty periods and collect expiring entries ---
lv_today = sy-datum.

" Calculate remaining days and filter by lead time
lv_days = lv_end - lv_today.
ls_output-resttage = lv_days.

IF lv_days >= 0 AND lv_days <= p_rest.
  APPEND ls_output TO lt_output.
ENDIF.

" --- Determine if email notification is needed ---
lv_mail_needed = abap_false.
LOOP AT lt_output INTO ls_output.
  IF ls_output-resttage < p_rest.
    lv_mail_needed = abap_true.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

" --- Send email if required ---
IF p_send = 'X' AND p_email IS NOT INITIAL AND lv_mail_needed = abap_true.
  PERFORM send_email USING p_email lt_output.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Sharing Custom Function Module ZPOPUP_TO_GET_ONE_VALUE for Simple User Input
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community! ðŸ‘‹

Today Iâ€™d like to share a small but useful development I recently created â€” a reusable function module that displays a popup to collect a single value entered by the user.

The idea was to create a lightweight and generic solution to obtain user input through a popup, similar to some standard dialogs but fully customizable and easy to reuse across different programs and languages.

The function module was implemented in the standard function group SPO3, and I created a custom screen 101 specifically for this purpose. The screen contains a single input field and standard OK/Cancel buttons, providing a very simple user interaction.  Also, to allow the user to select a date using the standard SAP Calendar, I added the search help BU_DATE_CHAR to the input field.

Final Result:

Sample Code:

FUNCTION ZPOPUP_TO_GET_ONE_VALUE.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Interface local:
*"  EXPORTING
*"     VALUE(ANSWER)
*"     VALUE(VALUE1) TYPE  BAPI2017_GM_HEAD_01-PSTNG_DATE
*"  EXCEPTIONS
*"      TITEL_TOO_LONG
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  ANSWER = 'J'.

  IF sy-langu = 'P'.
    MOVE 'ConfirmaÃ§Ã£o' TO GL_TITEL.
  ELSEIF sy-langu = 'E'.
    MOVE 'Confirmation' TO GL_TITEL.
  ELSEIF sy-langu = 'D'.
    MOVE 'BestÃ¤tigung' TO GL_TITEL.
  ELSEIF sy-langu = 'S'.
    MOVE 'ConfirmaciÃ³n' TO GL_TITEL.
  ELSEIF sy-langu = 'F'.
    MOVE 'Confirmation' TO GL_TITEL.
  ENDIF.

  CLEAR SPOP-VARVALUE1.

  CALL SCREEN 101 STARTING AT 25  6
                  ENDING   AT 90 8.

  VALUE1 = SPOP-VARVALUE1.
  ANSWER = ANTWORT.

ENDFUNCTION.

General Attribute List of the Elements on Screen 101: 

This small development provides a straightforward method to collect a single user input without repeatedly building a full dynpro from scratch. If you have suggestions for improvements or alternative approaches, Iâ€™d be happy to hear your thoughts!

Thanks for reading! ðŸ‘‹

entry.title: Custom Development: Program for Mass Creation of Purchase Requisitions
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community! ðŸ‘‹

Today Iâ€™d like to share a custom ABAP Development that I created to simplify and automate a very common operational need: the mass creation of Purchase Requisitions (PRs).

In many organizations, users frequently need to create large volumes of PRs based on spreadsheets, external data, or recurring patterns. Doing this manually through ME51N can be time-consuming, error-prone, and inefficient.

To address this, I developed a standalone program that reads structured input data and automatically creates PRs in bulk, providing clear logs and validation checks.

Report ZMM_LOG_PG03:

REPORT zmm_log_pg03.

INCLUDE:
  zmm_log_pg03_top,
  zmm_log_pg03_lcl,
  zmm_log_pg03_scr,
  zmm_log_pg03_f01.

Include ZMM_LOG_PG03_TOP:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Include          ZMM_LOG_PG01_TOP
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*


TYPES:
  BEGIN OF gtyp_post.
    INCLUDE TYPE zmm_log_st03.
TYPES:
    bsart TYPE bbsrt,
    knttp TYPE knttp,
    ernam TYPE ernam,
    kostl TYPE kostl,
    ekorg TYPE ekorg,
    ekgrp TYPE ekgrp,
  END OF gtyp_post,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_imp_exp,
    matnr	TYPE matnr,
    menge	TYPE char16,
    werks	TYPE werks_d,
    lgort	TYPE lgort_d,
    lfdat	TYPE char10,
    flief	TYPE flief,
  END OF gtyp_imp_exp,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_imp_exp_ini,
    matnr	TYPE string,
    menge	TYPE string,
    werks	TYPE string,
    lgort	TYPE string,
    lfdat	TYPE string,
    flief	TYPE string,
  END OF gtyp_imp_exp_ini,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_num_errors,
    index TYPE sytabix,
    value TYPE char20,
  END OF gtyp_num_errors,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_date_errors,
    index TYPE sytabix,
    value TYPE char20,
  END OF gtyp_date_errors.


CONSTANTS:
  gc_matkl TYPE rvari_vnam VALUE 'ZMMPURREQ_MATGROUP'.

CLASS: lcl_eventhandler DEFINITION DEFERRED.

DATA:
  BEGIN: OF gt_excl OCCURS 0,
    code TYPE syst_ucomm,
  END OF gt_excl.

DATA:
  gt_out             TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zmm_log_st03,
  gt_out_ini         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zmm_log_st03,
  gs_out             TYPE zmm_log_st03,
  gt_post            TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_post,
  gs_post            TYPE gtyp_post,
  gt_import          TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_imp_exp,
  gt_num_errors      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_num_errors WITH KEY index,
  gs_num_errors      TYPE gtyp_num_errors,
  gt_date_errors     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_date_errors WITH KEY index,
  gs_date_errors     TYPE gtyp_date_errors,
  gt_protocol_import TYPE lvc_t_msg1,
  gt_rows            TYPE lvc_t_row,
  gs_rows            TYPE lvc_s_row,
  gr_matkl           TYPE RANGE OF matkl,
  gs_matkl           LIKE LINE OF gr_matkl,
  go_container       TYPE REF TO cl_gui_custom_container,
  go_alv             TYPE REF TO cl_gui_alv_grid,
  go_events          TYPE REF TO lcl_eventhandler,
  gv_answer          TYPE char1,
  gv_import          TYPE xfeld,
  gv_progress        TYPE xfeld,
  gv_errors          TYPE xfeld,
  gv_rows            TYPE int4,
  gv_selall          TYPE xfeld.

Include ZMM_LOG_PG03_LCL:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Include          ZMM_LOG_PG01_LCL
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*

CLASS lcl_eventhandler DEFINITION.

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    CLASS-METHODS:

      handle_data_changed FOR EVENT data_changed OF cl_gui_alv_grid
        IMPORTING
          er_data_changed.


ENDCLASS.                    "lcl_eventhandler DEFINITION

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*       CLASS lcl_eventhandler IMPLEMENTATION
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
CLASS lcl_eventhandler IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD handle_data_changed.

    CONSTANTS:
      lv_tabname TYPE tabname VALUE 'ZMM_LOG_ST03'.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS:
      <lfs_value>         TYPE any,
      <lfs_value_o>       TYPE any,
      <lv_value_ref>      TYPE any,
      <lfs_ls_add_fields> TYPE dcfielddat.

    DATA:
      lo_data_changed    TYPE REF TO cl_alv_changed_data_protocol,
      lo_struct          TYPE REF TO cl_abap_structdescr,
      lr_data            TYPE REF TO data,
      lt_comp            TYPE abap_component_tab,
      ls_comp            TYPE abap_componentdescr,
      ls_protocol_import TYPE lvc_s_msg1,
      lt_failure         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ddfkeyrc,
      ls_failure         TYPE ddfkeyrc,
      lt_add_fields      TYPE dcfielddats,
      ls_good_cell       TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      ls_mod_cell        TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      ls_mod_cell2       TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      ls_mod_cell_add    TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      lv_value           TYPE lvc_value,
      lv_value_o         TYPE lvc_value,
      ls_out             TYPE zmm_log_st03,
      lv_row_id          TYPE int4,
      lv_fieldn	         TYPE lvc_fname,
      lv_fieldname       TYPE fnam_____4,
      ls_syst            TYPE syst,
      lv_msgno           TYPE symsgno,
      lv_msgv1           TYPE char120,
      lv_msgv2           TYPE char120,
      lv_msgv3           TYPE char120,
      lv_proc_f          TYPE f,
      lv_proc            TYPE sy-tabix,
      lv_werks           TYPE werks_d,
      lv_lgort           TYPE lgort_d,
      lv_matnr           TYPE matnr,
      lv_mmsta           TYPE mmsta,
      lv_lifnr           TYPE lifnr,
      lv_datbi           TYPE datbi,
      lv_lines           TYPE i,
      lv_date_format(15) TYPE c.


    IF er_data_changed IS NOT BOUND.
      EXIT.
    ENDIF.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL.

      FREE: er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells.

      lo_struct ?= cl_abap_typedescr=>describe_by_data( ls_out ).
      lt_comp = lo_struct->get_components( ).

      LOOP AT gt_out INTO ls_out.
        lv_row_id = sy-tabix.
        LOOP AT lt_comp INTO ls_comp.
          lv_fieldn = ls_comp-name.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_fieldn OF STRUCTURE ls_out TO <lfs_value_o>.
          IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL AND <lfs_value_o> IS ASSIGNED.
            er_data_changed->modify_cell(
              i_row_id    = lv_row_id
              i_tabix     = lv_row_id
              i_fieldname = lv_fieldn
              i_value     = <lfs_value_o>
            ).
            UNASSIGN <lfs_value_o>.
          ENDIF.
        ENDLOOP.
      ENDLOOP.

      gt_protocol_import = er_data_changed->mt_protocol.

    ELSE.

      LOOP AT er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells INTO ls_mod_cell.
        DELETE gt_protocol_import WHERE row_id = ls_mod_cell-row_id AND fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname.
      ENDLOOP.
      FREE: er_data_changed->mt_protocol.
      CALL METHOD er_data_changed->refresh_protocol.
      LOOP AT gt_protocol_import INTO ls_protocol_import.
        CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = ls_protocol_import-msgid
            i_msgty     = ls_protocol_import-msgty
            i_msgno     = ls_protocol_import-msgno
            i_msgv1     = ls_protocol_import-msgv1
            i_msgv2     = ls_protocol_import-msgv2
            i_msgv3     = ls_protocol_import-msgv3
            i_msgv4     = ls_protocol_import-msgv4
            i_fieldname = ls_protocol_import-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_protocol_import-row_id.
      ENDLOOP.


    ENDIF.


    DESCRIBE TABLE er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells LINES lv_lines.

    LOOP AT er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells INTO ls_mod_cell.

      READ TABLE gt_out INTO ls_out INDEX  ls_mod_cell-row_id.

      lv_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname.
      IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL.
        ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_fieldname OF STRUCTURE ls_out TO <lfs_value_o>.
        lv_value_o = <lfs_value_o>.

* EXT_DMSF (23/09/2025) - START

        lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.

        IF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'MATNR'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '197'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_fieldname = 'MENGE'.
          SHIFT lv_value_o LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
          IF lv_value_o = '' OR lv_value_o = '0.000'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '198'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
          ENDIF.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'WERKS'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '199'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'LGORT'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '200'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'LFDAT'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '201'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'FLIEF'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '202'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ENDIF.

* END

      ELSE.
        lv_value_o = ls_mod_cell-value.
      ENDIF.

      FREE: gs_post.
      READ TABLE gt_post INTO gs_post INDEX ls_mod_cell-row_id.


      CASE ls_mod_cell-fieldname.
        WHEN 'MATNR' OR 'WERKS' OR 'LGORT'.
          FREE: lt_failure, lt_add_fields.
          IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.
            CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_MATN1_INPUT'
              EXPORTING
                input         = lv_value_o
              IMPORTING
                output        = lv_value_o.
          ENDIF.
          CALL FUNCTION 'DDUT_INPUT_CHECK'
            EXPORTING
              tabname           = lv_tabname
              fieldname         = lv_fieldname
              value             = lv_value_o
            TABLES
              failure_tab       = lt_failure
            CHANGING
              additional_fields = lt_add_fields
            EXCEPTIONS
              no_ddic_field     = 1
              illegal_move      = 2
              OTHERS            = 3.
          IF lt_add_fields IS NOT INITIAL.
            LOOP AT lt_add_fields ASSIGNING <lfs_ls_add_fields>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT <lfs_ls_add_fields>-fieldname OF STRUCTURE ls_out TO <lfs_value>.
              IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL AND <lfs_value> IS ASSIGNED.
                ASSIGN <lfs_ls_add_fields>-value->* TO <lv_value_ref>.
                IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL AND <lv_value_ref> IS ASSIGNED.
                  ASSIGN <lfs_ls_add_fields>-value->* TO <lv_value_ref>.
                  <lv_value_ref> =  <lfs_value>.
                  <lfs_ls_add_fields>-found =  abap_true.
                  UNASSIGN <lv_value_ref>.
                ENDIF.
                UNASSIGN <lfs_value>.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
            REFRESH: lt_failure.
            CALL FUNCTION 'DDUT_INPUT_CHECK'
              EXPORTING
                tabname           = lv_tabname
                fieldname         = lv_fieldname
                value             = lv_value_o
              TABLES
                failure_tab       = lt_failure
              CHANGING
                additional_fields = lt_add_fields
              EXCEPTIONS
                no_ddic_field     = 1
                illegal_move      = 2
                OTHERS            = 3.
          ENDIF.
          IF lt_failure IS NOT INITIAL.
            LOOP AT lt_failure INTO ls_failure.
              ls_failure-arbgb = 'ZMM'.
              lv_msgno = ls_failure-msgnr.
              IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'WERKS'.
                lv_msgno = 184.
                ls_failure-msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT ls_failure-msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
              ELSEIF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'LGORT'.
                lv_msgno = 185.
                ls_failure-msgv1 = ls_out-lgort.
                ls_failure-msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT ls_failure-msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                ls_failure-msgv3 = ls_out-werks.
              ELSEIF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.
                lv_msgno = 181.
                ls_failure-msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT ls_failure-msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                ls_failure-msgv3 = lv_werks.
                ls_failure-msgv4 = ls_out-lgort.
              ENDIF.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = ls_failure-arbgb
                  i_msgty     = ls_failure-msgty
                  i_msgno     = lv_msgno
                  i_msgv1     = ls_failure-msgv1
                  i_msgv2     = ls_failure-msgv2
                  i_msgv3     = ls_failure-msgv3
                  i_msgv4     = ls_failure-msgv4
                  i_fieldname = ls_failure-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDLOOP.
          ELSE.
            IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.

              SELECT SINGLE matnr
                  FROM mara
                 WHERE matnr = @LV_value_o
                  INTO @LV_matnr.
              IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
                lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                  EXPORTING
                    i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                    i_msgty     = 'E'
                    i_msgno     = 179
                    i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                    i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                    i_msgv3     = lv_werks
                    i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                    i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
              ENDIF.

              SELECT SINGLE matnr
                  FROM mara
                 WHERE matnr = @LV_value_o
                   AND matkl IN @GR_matkl
                  INTO @LV_matnr.
              IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
                lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                READ TABLE gr_matkl INTO gs_matkl INDEX 1.
                IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
                  lv_msgv3 = gs_matkl-low.
                ENDIF.
                SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                  EXPORTING
                    i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                    i_msgty     = 'E'
                    i_msgno     = 180
                    i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                    i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                    i_msgv3     = lv_msgv3
                    i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                    i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
              ENDIF.

              lv_werks = ls_out-werks.
              IF lv_value_o IS NOT INITIAL AND lv_werks IS NOT INITIAL.
                SELECT SINGLE mmsta
                  FROM marc
                 WHERE matnr = @LV_value_o
                   AND werks = @LV_werks
                   AND mmsta IS INITIAL
                  INTO @LV_mmsta.
                IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
                  lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                  SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                  CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                    EXPORTING
                      i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                      i_msgty     = 'E'
                      i_msgno     = 182
                      i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                      i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                      i_msgv3     = lv_werks
                      i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                      i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                ENDIF.
              ENDIF.
            ENDIF.

          ENDIF.


          IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.
            FREE: lv_value.
            SELECT SINGLE maktx
              INTO lv_value
              FROM makt
             WHERE matnr = lv_value_o
               AND spras = sy-langu.
            er_data_changed->modify_cell(
              i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id
              i_fieldname = 'MAKTX'
              i_value     = lv_value
            ).


            IF gs_post-bsart IS INITIAL.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'E'
                  i_msgno     = 188
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.

            IF gs_post-knttp IS INITIAL.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'E'
                  i_msgno     = 189
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.

            IF gs_post-ekorg IS INITIAL OR gs_post-ekgrp IS INITIAL.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'E'
                  i_msgno     = 191
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.


*                bsart TYPE bbsrt,
*    knttp TYPE knttp,
*    ernam TYPE ernam,
*    kostl TYPE kostl,
*    ekorg TYPE ekorg,
*    ekgrp TYPE ekgrp,
          ENDIF.


        WHEN 'LFDAT'.
          READ TABLE gt_date_errors WITH KEY index = ls_mod_cell-row_id
                                    TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
          IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
*            IF ls_mod_cell-value <> sy-datum.
            IF lv_value_o <> sy-datum. " EXT_DMSF (26/09/2025)
              WRITE ls_mod_cell-row_id TO lv_msgv1 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'W'
                  i_msgno     = 192
                  i_msgv1     = lv_msgv1
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.
          ENDIF.

        WHEN 'FLIEF'.
          UNPACK lv_value_o TO lv_lifnr.
          SELECT SINGLE lifnr
            INTO lv_lifnr
            FROM lfm1
           WHERE lifnr = lv_lifnr
             AND ekorg = gs_post-ekorg.
          IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
            lv_msgv2 = gs_post-ekorg.
            CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
              EXPORTING
                i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                i_msgty     = 'E'
                i_msgno     = 187
                i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
          ENDIF.

      ENDCASE.

    ENDLOOP.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL AND gt_num_errors IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT gt_num_errors INTO gs_num_errors.
        WRITE gs_num_errors-value TO lv_msgv1 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        WRITE gs_num_errors-index TO lv_msgv2 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = 183
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv1
            i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = 'MENGE'
            i_row_id    = gs_num_errors-index.
*        er_data_changed->modify_cell(
*          i_row_id    = gs_num_errors-index
*          i_fieldname = 'MENGE'
*          i_value     = gs_num_errors-value
*        ).
      ENDLOOP.
      FREE: gt_num_errors.
    ENDIF.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL AND gt_date_errors IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT gt_date_errors INTO gs_date_errors.
        WRITE gs_date_errors-value TO lv_msgv1 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        WRITE gs_date_errors-index TO lv_msgv2 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = 186
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv1
            i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = 'LFDAT'
            i_row_id    = gs_date_errors-index.
        er_data_changed->modify_cell(
          i_row_id    = gs_date_errors-index
          i_fieldname = 'LFDAT'
          i_value     = gs_date_errors-value
        ).
      ENDLOOP.
      FREE: gt_date_errors.
    ENDIF.


    CALL METHOD er_data_changed->display_protocol.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL.
      FREE: gv_import.
      gt_protocol_import = er_data_changed->mt_protocol.
      CALL METHOD go_alv->refresh_table_display.
    ENDIF.
    FREE: gv_progress.

    IF er_data_changed->mt_protocol IS INITIAL.
      FREE: gv_errors.
    ELSE.
      READ TABLE er_data_changed->mt_protocol WITH KEY msgty = 'E'
                                              TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
      IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
        gv_errors = abap_true.
      ELSE.
        FREE: gv_errors.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.                    "lcl_eventhandler IMPLEMENTATION
